9.31: Meanwhile, the flax and barley crops had been destroyed by the storm because they were ready to ripen.
9.32: But the wheat crops ripen later, and they were not damaged.
9.33: After Moses left the royal palace and the city, he lifted his arms in prayer to the LORD, and the thunder, hail, and drenching rain stopped.
9.34: When the king realized that the storm was over, he disobeyed once more. He and his officials were so stubborn
9.35: that he refused to let the Israelites go. This was exactly what the LORD had said would happen.

10.1: The LORD said to Moses: Go back to the king. I have made him and his officials stubborn, so that I could work these miracles.
10.2: I did this because I want you to tell your children and your grandchildren about my miracles and about my harsh treatment of the Egyptians. Then all of you will know that I am the LORD.
10.3: Moses and Aaron went to the king and told him that the LORD God of the Hebrews had said: How long will you stubbornly refuse to obey? Release my people so they can worship me.
10.4: Do this by tomorrow, or I will cover your country with so many locusts
10.5: that you won't be able to see the ground. Most of your crops were ruined by the hailstones, but these locusts will destroy what little is left, including the trees.
10.6: Your palace, the homes of your officials, and all the other houses in Egypt will overflow with more locusts than have ever been seen in this country. After Moses left the palace,
10.7: the king's officials asked, "Your Majesty, how much longer is this man going to be a troublemaker? Why don't you let the people leave, so they can worship the LORD their God? Don't you know that Egypt is a disaster?"
10.8: The king had Moses and Aaron brought back, and he said, "All right, you may go and worship the LORD your God. But first tell me who will be going."
10.9: "Everyone, young and old," Moses answered. "We will even take our sheep, goats, and cattle, because we want to hold a celebration in honor of the LORD."
10.10: The king replied, "The LORD had better watch over you on the day I let you leave with your families! You're up to no good.
10.11: Do you want to worship the LORD? All right, take only the men and go." Then Moses and Aaron were chased out of the palace.
10.12: The LORD told Moses, "Stretch your arm toward Egypt. Swarms of locusts will come and eat everything left by the hail."
10.13: Moses held out his walking stick, and the LORD sent an east wind that blew across Egypt the rest of the day and all that night. By morning, locusts
10.14: were swarming everywhere. Never before had there been so many locusts in Egypt, and never again will there be so many.
10.15: The ground was black with locusts, and they ate everything left on the trees and in the fields. Nothing green remained in Egypt--not a tree or a plant.
10.16: At once the king sent for Moses and Aaron. He told them, "I have sinned against the LORD your God and against you.
10.17: Forgive me one more time and ask the LORD to stop these insects from killing every living plant."
10.18: Moses left the palace and prayed.
10.19: Then the LORD sent a strong west wind that swept the locusts into the Red Sea. Not one locust was left anywhere in Egypt,
10.20: but the LORD made the king so stubborn that he still refused to let the Israelites go.
10.21: The LORD said to Moses, "Stretch your arm toward the sky, and everything will be covered with darkness thick enough to touch."
10.22: Moses stretched his arm toward the sky, and Egypt was covered with darkness for three days.
10.23: During that time, the Egyptians could not see each other or leave their homes, but there was light where the Israelites lived.
10.24: The king sent for Moses and told him, "Go worship the LORD! And take your families with you. Just leave your sheep, goats, and cattle."
10.25: "No!" Moses replied. "You must let us offer sacrifices to the LORD our God,
10.26: and we won't know which animals we will need until we get there. That's why we can't leave even one of them here."
10.27: This time the LORD made the king so stubborn
10.28: that he said to Moses, "Get out and stay out! If you ever come back, you're dead!"
10.29: "Have it your way," Moses answered. "You won't see me again."

11.1: The LORD said to Moses: I am going to punish the king of Egypt and his people one more time. Then the king will gladly let you leave his land. In fact, he will even chase you out.
11.2: Now go and tell my people to ask their Egyptian neighbors for gold and silver jewelry.
11.3: So the LORD made the Egyptians greatly respect the Israelites, and everyone, including the king's officials, considered Moses an important leader.
11.4: Moses went to the king and said: I have come to let you know what the LORD is going to do. About midnight he will go through the land of Egypt,
11.5: and wherever he goes, the first-born son in every family will die. Your own son will die, and so will the son of the lowest slave woman. Even the first-born males of your cattle will die.
11.6: Everywhere in Egypt there will be loud crying. Nothing like this has ever happened before or will ever happen again.
11.7: But there won't be any need for the Israelites to cry. Things will be so quiet that not even a dog will be heard barking. Then you Egyptians will know that the LORD is good to the Israelites, even while he punishes you.
11.8: Your leaders will come and bow down, begging me to take my people and leave your country. Then we will leave. Moses was very angry; he turned and left the king.
11.9: What the LORD had earlier said to Moses came true. He had said, "The king of Egypt won't listen. Then I will perform even more miracles."
11.10: So the king of Egypt saw Moses and Aaron work miracles, but the LORD made him stubbornly refuse to let the Israelites leave his country.

12.1: Some time later the LORD said to Moses and Aaron:
12.2: This month is to be the first month of the year for you.
12.3: Tell the people of Israel that on the tenth day of this month the head of each family must choose a lamb or a young goat for his family to eat.
12.6: Each family must take care of its animal until the evening of the fourteenth day of the month, when the animals are to be killed.
12.7: Some of the blood must be put on the two doorposts and above the door of each house where the animals are to be eaten.
12.8: That night the animals are to be roasted and eaten, together with bitter herbs and thin bread made without yeast.
12.9: Don't eat the meat raw or boiled. The entire animal, including its head, legs, and insides, must be roasted.
12.10: Eat what you want that night, and the next morning burn whatever is left.
12.11: When you eat the meal, be dressed and ready to travel. Have your sandals on, carry your walking stick in your hand, and eat quickly. This is the Passover Festival in honor of me, your LORD.
12.12: That same night I will pass through Egypt and kill the first-born son in every family and the first-born male of all animals. I am the LORD, and I will punish the gods of Egypt.
12.13: The blood on the houses will show me where you live, and when I see the blood, I will pass over you. Then you won't be bothered by the terrible disasters I will bring on Egypt.
12.14: Remember this day and celebrate it each year as a festival in my honor.
12.15: For seven days you must eat bread made without yeast. And on the first of these seven days, you must remove all yeast from your homes. If you eat anything made with yeast during this festival, you will no longer be part of Israel.
12.16: Meet together for worship on the first and seventh days of the festival. The only work you are allowed to do on either of these two days is that of preparing the bread.
12.17: Celebrate this Festival of Thin Bread as a way of remembering the day that I brought your families and tribes out of Egypt. And do this each year.
12.18: Begin on the evening of the fourteenth day of the first month by eating bread made without yeast. Then continue this celebration until the evening of the twenty-first day.
12.19: During these seven days no yeast is allowed in anyone's home, whether they are native Israelites or not. If you are caught eating anything made with yeast, you will no longer be part of Israel.
12.20: Stay away from yeast, no matter where you live. No one is allowed to eat anything made with yeast!
12.21: Moses called the leaders of Israel together and said: Each family is to pick out a sheep and kill it for Passover.
12.22: Make a brush from a few small branches of a hyssop plant and dip the brush in the bowl that has the blood of the animal in it. Then brush some of the blood above the door and on the posts at each side of the door of your house. After this, everyone is to stay inside until morning.
12.23: During that night the LORD will go through the country of Egypt and kill the first-born son in every Egyptian family. He will see where you have put the blood, and he will not come into your house. His angel that brings death will pass over and not kill your first-born sons.
12.26: Your children will ask you, "What are we celebrating?"
12.27: And you will answer, "The Passover animal is killed to honor the LORD. We do these things because on that night long ago the LORD passed over the homes of our people in Egypt. He killed the first-born sons of the Egyptians, but he spared our children from death." After Moses finished speaking, the people of Israel knelt down and worshiped the LORD.
12.28: Then they left and did what Moses and Aaron had told them to do.
12.29: At midnight the LORD killed the first-born son of every Egyptian family, from the son of the king to the son of every prisoner in jail. He also killed the first-born male of every animal that belonged to the Egyptians.
12.30: That night the king, his officials, and everyone else in Egypt got up and started crying bitterly. In every Egyptian home, someone was dead.
12.31: During the night the king sent for Moses and Aaron and told them, "Get your people out of my country and leave us alone! Go and worship the LORD, as you have asked.
12.32: Take your sheep, goats, and cattle, and get out. But ask your God to be kind to me."
12.33: The Egyptians did everything they could to get the Israelites to leave their country as quickly as possible. They said, "Please hurry and leave. If you don't, we will all be dead."
12.34: So the Israelites quickly made some bread dough and put it in pans. But they did not mix any yeast in the dough to make it rise. They wrapped cloth around the pans and carried them on their shoulders.
12.35: The Israelites had already done what Moses had told them to do. They had gone to their Egyptian neighbors and asked for gold and silver and for clothes.
12.36: The LORD had made the Egyptians friendly toward the people of Israel, and they gave them whatever they asked for. In this way they carried away the wealth of the Egyptians when they left Egypt.
12.37: The Israelites walked from the city of Rameses to the city of Succoth. There were about 600,000 of them, not counting women and children.
12.38: Many other people went with them as well, and there were also a lot of sheep, goats, and cattle.
12.39: They left Egypt in such a hurry that they did not have time to prepare any food except the bread dough made without yeast. So they baked it and made thin bread.
12.42: On that night the LORD kept watch for them, and on this same night each year Israel will always keep watch in honor of the LORD.
12.43: The LORD gave Moses and Aaron the following instructions for celebrating Passover: Only Israelites may eat the Passover meal.
12.44: Your slaves may eat the meal if they have been circumcised,
12.45: but no foreigners who work for you are allowed to have any.
12.46: The entire meal must be eaten inside, and no one may leave the house during the celebration. No bones of the Passover lamb may be broken.
12.47: And all Israelites must take part in the meal.
12.48: If anyone who isn't an Israelite wants to celebrate Passover with you, every man and boy in that family must first be circumcised. Then they may join in the meal, just like native Israelites. No uncircumcised man or boy may eat the Passover meal!
12.49: This law applies both to native Israelites and to those foreigners who live among you.
12.50: The Israelites obeyed everything the LORD had commanded Moses and Aaron to tell them.
12.51: And on that same day the LORD brought Israel's families and tribes out of Egypt.

13.2: "Dedicate to me the first-born son of every family and the first-born males of your flocks and herds. These belong to me."
13.5: The LORD promised your ancestors that he would bring you into the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Hivites, and Jebusites. It is a land rich with milk and honey. Each year during the month of Abib, celebrate these events in the following way:
13.6: For seven days you are to eat bread made without yeast, and on the seventh day you are to celebrate a festival in honor of the LORD.
13.7: During those seven days, you must not eat anything made with yeast or even have yeast anywhere near your homes.
13.8: Then on the seventh day you must explain to your children that you do this because the LORD brought you out of Egypt.
13.9: This celebration will be like wearing a sign on your hand or on your forehead, because then you will pass on to others the teaching of the LORD, whose mighty power brought you out of Egypt.
13.10: Celebrate this festival each year at the same time.
13.11: The LORD will give you the land of the Canaanites, just as he promised you and your ancestors.
13.12: From then on, you must give him every first-born son from your families and every first-born male from your animals, because these belong to him.
13.13: You can spare the life of a first-born donkey by sacrificing a lamb; if you don't, you must break the donkey's neck. You must spare every first-born son.
13.14: In the future your children will ask what this ceremony means. Explain it to them by saying, "The LORD used his mighty power to rescue us from slavery in Egypt.
13.15: The king stubbornly refused to set us free, so the LORD killed the first-born male of every animal and the first-born son of every Egyptian family. This is why we sacrifice to the LORD every first-born male of every animal and save every first-born son."
13.16: This ceremony will serve the same purpose as a sign on your hand or on your forehead to tell how the LORD's mighty power rescued us from Egypt.
13.17: After the king had finally let the people go, the LORD did not lead them through Philistine territory, though that was the shortest way. God had said, "If they are attacked, they may decide to return to Egypt."
13.18: So he led them around through the desert and toward the Red Sea. The Israelites left Egypt, prepared for battle.
13.19: Moses had them take the bones of Joseph, whose dying words had been, "God will come to your rescue, and when he does, be sure to take my bones with you."
13.20: The people of Israel left Succoth and camped at Etham at the border of Egypt near the desert.

14.1: At Etham the LORD said to Moses:
14.2: Tell the people of Israel to turn back and camp across from Pi-Hahiroth near Baal-Zephon, between Migdol and the Red Sea.
14.3: The king will think you were afraid to cross the desert and that you are wandering around, trying to find another way to leave the country.
14.4: I will make the king stubborn again, and he will try to catch you. Then I will destroy him and his army. People everywhere will praise me for my victory, and the Egyptians will know that I really am the LORD. The Israelites obeyed the LORD and camped where he told them.
14.5: When the king of Egypt heard that the Israelites had finally left, he and his officials changed their minds and said, "Look what we have done! We let them get away, and they will no longer be our slaves."
14.6: The king got his war chariot and army ready.
14.7: He commanded his officers in charge of his 600 best chariots and all his other chariots to start after the Israelites.
14.8: The LORD made the king so stubborn that he went after them, while the Israelites proudly went on their way.
14.9: But the king's horses and chariots and soldiers caught up with them while they were camping by the Red Sea near Pi-Hahiroth and Baal-Zephon.
14.10: When the Israelites saw the king coming with his army, they were frightened and begged the LORD for help.
14.11: They also complained to Moses, "Wasn't there enough room in Egypt to bury us? Is that why you brought us out here to die in the desert? Why did you bring us out of Egypt anyway?
14.12: While we were there, didn't we tell you to leave us alone? We'd rather be slaves in Egypt than die in this desert!"
14.13: But Moses answered, "Don't be afraid! Be brave, and you will see the LORD save you today. These Egyptians will never bother you again.
14.14: The LORD will fight for you, and you won't have to do a thing."
14.15: The LORD said to Moses, "Why do you keep calling out to me for help? Tell the Israelites to move forward.
14.16: Then hold your walking stick over the sea. The water will open up and make a road where they can walk through on dry ground.
14.17: I will make the Egyptians so stubborn that they will go after you. Then I will be praised because of what happens to the king and his chariots and cavalry.
14.18: The Egyptians will know for sure that I am the LORD."
14.19: All this time God's angel had gone ahead of Israel's army, but now he moved behind them. A large cloud had also gone ahead of them,
14.20: but now it moved between the Egyptians and the Israelites. The cloud gave light to the Israelites, but made it dark for the Egyptians, and during the night they could not come any closer.
14.21: Moses stretched his arm over the sea, and the LORD sent a strong east wind that blew all night until there was dry land where the water had been. The sea opened up,
14.22: and the Israelites walked through on dry land with a wall of water on each side.
14.23: The Egyptian chariots and cavalry went after them.
14.24: But before daylight the LORD looked down at the Egyptian army from the fiery cloud and made them panic.
14.25: Their chariot wheels got stuck, and it was hard for them to move. So the Egyptians said to one another, "Let's leave these people alone! The LORD is on their side and is fighting against us."
14.26: The LORD told Moses, "Stretch your arm toward the sea--the water will cover the Egyptians and their cavalry and chariots."
14.27: Moses stretched out his arm, and at daybreak the water rushed toward the Egyptians. They tried to run away, but the LORD drowned them in the sea.
14.28: The water came and covered the chariots, the cavalry, and the whole Egyptian army that had followed the Israelites into the sea. Not one of them was left alive.
14.29: But the sea had made a wall of water on each side of the Israelites, so they walked through on dry land.
14.30: On that day, when the Israelites saw the bodies of the Egyptians washed up on the shore, they knew that the LORD had saved them.
14.31: Because of the mighty power he had used against the Egyptians, the Israelites worshiped him and trusted him and his servant Moses.

15.1: Moses and the Israelites sang this song in praise of the LORD: I sing praises to the LORD for his great victory! He has thrown the horses and their riders into the sea.
15.2: The LORD is my strength, the reason for my song, because he has saved me. I praise and honor the LORD--he is my God and the God of my ancestors.
15.3: The LORD is his name, and he is a warrior!
15.4: He threw the chariots and army of Egypt's king into the Red Sea, and he drowned the best of the king's officers.
15.5: They sank to the bottom just like stones.
15.6: With the tremendous force of your right arm, our LORD, you crushed your enemies.
15.7: What a great victory was yours, when you defeated everyone who opposed you. Your fiery anger wiped them out, as though they were straw.
15.8: You were so furious that the sea piled up like a wall, and the ocean depths curdled like cheese.
15.9: Your enemies boasted that they would pursue and capture us, divide up our possessions, treat us as they wished, then take out their swords and kill us right there.
15.10: But when you got furious, they sank like lead, swallowed by ocean waves.
15.11: Our LORD, no other gods compare with you--Majestic and holy! Fearsome and glorious! Miracle worker!
15.12: When you signaled with your right hand, your enemies were swallowed deep into the earth.
15.13: The people you rescued were led by your powerful love to your holy place.
15.14: Nations learned of this and trembled--Philistines shook with horror.
15.15: The leaders of Edom and of Moab were terrified. Everyone in Canaan fainted,
15.16: struck down by fear. Our LORD, your powerful arm kept them still as a rock until the people you rescued to be your very own had marched by.
15.17: You will let your people settle on your own mountain, where you chose to live and to be worshiped.
15.18: Our LORD, you will rule forever!
15.19: The LORD covered the royal Egyptian cavalry and chariots with the sea, after the Israelites had walked safely through on dry ground.
15.20: Miriam the sister of Aaron was a prophet. So she took her tambourine and led the other women out to play their tambourines and to dance.
15.21: Then she sang to them: "Sing praises to the LORD for his great victory! He has thrown the horses and their riders into the sea."
15.22: After the Israelites left the Red Sea, Moses led them through the Shur Desert for three days, before finding water.
15.23: They did find water at Marah, but it was bitter, which is how that place got its name.
15.24: The people complained and said, "Moses, what are we going to drink?"
15.25: Moses asked the LORD for help, and the LORD told him to throw a certain piece of wood into the water. Moses did so, and the water became fit to drink. At Marah the LORD tested his people and also gave them some laws and teachings.
15.26: Then he said, "I am the LORD your God, and I cure your diseases. If you obey me by doing right and by following my laws and teachings, I won't punish you with the diseases I sent on the Egyptians."
15.27: Later the Israelites came to Elim, where there were twelve springs and 70 palm trees. So they camped there.

16.1: On the fifteenth day of the second month after the Israelites had escaped from Egypt, they left Elim and started through the western edge of the Sinai Desert in the direction of Mount Sinai.
16.2: There in the desert they started complaining to Moses and Aaron,
16.3: "We wish the LORD had killed us in Egypt. When we lived there, we could at least sit down and eat all the bread and meat we wanted. But you have brought us out here into this desert, where we are going to starve."
16.4: The LORD said to Moses, "I will send bread down from heaven like rain. Tell the people to go out each day and gather only enough for that day. That's how I will see if they obey me.
16.5: But on the sixth day of each week they must gather and cook twice as much."
16.6: Moses and Aaron told the people, "This evening you will know that the LORD was the one who rescued you from Egypt.
16.7: And in the morning you will see his glorious power, because he has heard your complaints against him. Why should you grumble to us? Who are we?"
16.8: Then Moses continued, "You will know it is the LORD when he gives you meat each evening and more than enough bread each morning. He is really the one you are complaining about, not us--we are nobodies--but the LORD has heard your complaints."
16.9: Moses turned to Aaron and said, "Bring the people together, because the LORD has heard their complaints."
16.10: Aaron was speaking to them, when everyone looked out toward the desert and saw the bright glory of the LORD in a cloud.
16.12: "I have heard my people complain. Now tell them that each evening they will have meat and each morning they will have more than enough bread. Then they will know that I am the LORD their God."
16.13: That evening a lot of quails came and landed everywhere in the camp, and the next morning dew covered the ground.
16.14: After the dew had gone, the desert was covered with thin flakes that looked like frost.
16.15: The people had never seen anything like this, and they started asking each other, "What is it?" Moses answered, "This is the bread that the LORD has given you to eat.
16.16: And he orders you to gather about two liters for each person in your family--that should be more than enough."
16.17: They did as they were told. Some gathered more and some gathered less.
16.18: Everyone had exactly what they needed, just the right amount.
16.19: Moses told them not to keep any overnight.
16.20: Some of them disobeyed, but the next morning what they kept was stinking and full of worms, and Moses was angry.
16.21: Each morning everyone gathered as much as they needed, and in the heat of the day the rest melted.
16.22: However, on the sixth day of the week, everyone gathered enough to have four liters, instead of two. When the leaders reported this to Moses,
16.23: he told them that the LORD had said, "Tomorrow is the Sabbath, a sacred day of rest in honor of me. So gather all you want to bake or boil, and make sure you save enough for tomorrow."
16.24: The people obeyed, and the next morning the food smelled fine and had no worms.
16.25: "You may eat the food," Moses said. "Today is the Sabbath in honor of the LORD, and there won't be any of this food on the ground today.
16.26: You will find it there for the first six days of the week, but not on the Sabbath."
16.27: A few of the Israelites did go out to look for some, but there was none.
16.28: Then the LORD said, "Moses, how long will you people keep disobeying my laws and teachings?
16.29: Remember that I was the one who gave you the Sabbath. That's why on the sixth day I provide enough bread for two days. Everyone is to stay home and rest on the Sabbath."
16.30: And so they rested on the Sabbath.
16.31: The Israelites called the bread manna. It was white like coriander seed and delicious as wafers made with honey.
16.32: Moses told the people that the LORD had said, "Store up two liters of this manna, because I want future generations to see the food I gave you during the time you were in the desert after I rescued you from Egypt."
16.33: Then Moses told Aaron, "Put some manna in a jar and store it in the place of worship for future generations to see."
16.34: Aaron followed the LORD's instructions and put the manna in front of the sacred chest for safekeeping.

17.1: The Israelites left the desert and moved from one place to another each time the LORD ordered them to. Once they camped at Rephidim, but there was no water for them to drink.
17.2: The people started complaining to Moses, "Give us some water!" Moses replied, "Why are you complaining to me and trying to put the LORD to the test?"
17.3: But the people were thirsty and kept on complaining, "Moses, did you bring us out of Egypt just to let us and our families and our animals die of thirst?"
17.4: Then Moses prayed to the LORD, "What am I going to do with these people? They are about to stone me to death!"
17.5: The LORD answered, "Take some of the leaders with you and go ahead of the rest of the people. Also take along the walking stick with which you struck the Nile River.
17.6: When you get to the rock at Mount Sinai, I will be there with you. Strike the rock with the stick, and water will pour out for the people to drink." Moses did this while the leaders watched.
17.7: The people had complained and tested the LORD by asking, "Is the LORD really with us?" So Moses named that place Massah, which means "testing" and Meribah, which means "complaining."
17.8: When the Israelites were at Rephidim, they were attacked by the Amalekites.
17.9: So Moses told Joshua, "Have some men ready to attack the Amalekites tomorrow. I will stand on a hilltop, holding this walking stick that has the power of God."
17.10: Joshua led the attack as Moses had commanded, while Moses, Aaron, and Hur stood on the hilltop.
17.11: The Israelites out-fought the Amalekites as long as Moses held up his arms, but they started losing whenever he lowered them.
17.12: After a while, his arms were so tired that Aaron and Hur got a rock for him to sit on. Then they stood beside him and supported his arms in the same position until sunset.
17.13: That's how Joshua defeated the Amalekites.
17.14: Afterwards, the LORD said to Moses, "Write an account of this victory and read it to Joshua. I want the Amalekites to be forgotten forever."
17.15: Moses built an altar and named it "The LORD Gives Me Victory."
17.16: Then Moses explained, "This is because I depended on the LORD. But in future generations, the LORD will fight the Amalekites again and again."

18.1: Jethro was the priest of Midian and the father-in-law of Moses. He heard what the LORD God had done for Moses and his people, after rescuing them from Egypt.
18.7: When they arrived, Moses went out and bowed down in front of Jethro, then kissed him. After they had greeted each other, they went into the tent,
18.8: where Moses told him everything the LORD had done to protect Israel against the Egyptians and their king. He also told him how the LORD had helped them in all of their troubles.
18.9: Jethro was so pleased to hear this good news about what the LORD had done,
18.10: that he shouted, "Praise the LORD! He rescued you and the Israelites from the Egyptians and their king.
18.11: Now I know that the LORD is the greatest God, because he has rescued Israel from their arrogant enemies."
18.12: Jethro offered sacrifices to God. Then Aaron and Israel's leaders came to eat with Jethro there at the place of worship.
18.13: The next morning Moses sat down at the place where he decided legal cases for the people, and everyone crowded around him until evening.
18.14: Jethro saw how much Moses had to do for the people, and he asked, "Why are you the only judge? Why do you let these people crowd around you from morning till evening?"
18.15: Moses answered, "Because they come here to find out what God wants them to do.
18.16: They bring their complaints to me, and I make decisions on the basis of God's laws."
18.17: Jethro replied: That isn't the best way to do it.
18.18: You and the people who come to you will soon be worn out. The job is too much for one person; you can't do it alone.
18.19: God will help you if you follow my advice. You should be the one to speak to God for the people,
18.20: and you should teach them God's laws and show them what they must do to live right.
18.21: You will need to appoint some competent leaders who respect God and are trustworthy and honest. Then put them over groups of 10, 50, 100, and 1,000.
18.22: These judges can handle the ordinary cases and bring the more difficult ones to you. Having them to share the load will make your work easier.
18.23: This is the way God wants it done. You won't be under nearly as much stress, and everyone else will return home feeling satisfied.
18.25: He chose some competent leaders from every tribe in Israel and put them over groups of 10, 50, 100, and 1,000.
18.26: They served as judges, deciding the easy cases themselves, but bringing the more difficult ones to Moses.
18.27: After Moses and his father-in-law Jethro had said goodbye to each other, Jethro returned home.

19.3: Moses went up the mountain to meet with the LORD God, who told him to say to the people:
19.4: You saw what I did in Egypt, and you know how I brought you here to me, just as a mighty eagle carries its young.
19.5: Now if you will faithfully obey me, you will be my very own people. The whole world is mine,
19.6: but you will be my holy nation and serve me as priests. Moses, that is what you must tell the Israelites.
19.7: After Moses went back, he reported to the leaders what the LORD had said,
19.8: and they all promised, "We will do everything the LORD has commanded." So Moses told the LORD about this.
19.9: The LORD said to Moses, "I will come to you in a thick cloud and let the people hear me speak to you. Then they will always trust you." Again Moses reported to the LORD what the people had said.
19.10: Once more the LORD spoke to Moses: Go back and tell the people that today and tomorrow they must get themselves ready to meet me. They must wash their clothes
19.11: and be ready by the day after tomorrow, when I will come down to Mount Sinai, where all of them can see me.
19.12: Warn the people that they are forbidden to touch any part of the mountain. Anyone who does will be put to death,
19.13: either with stones or arrows, and no one must touch the body of the person being put to death in this way. Even an animal that touches this mountain must be put to death. You may go up the mountain only after a signal is given on the trumpet.
19.14: After Moses went down the mountain, he gave orders for the people to wash their clothes and make themselves acceptable to worship God.
19.15: He told them to be ready in three days and not to have sex in the meantime.
19.16: On the morning of the third day there was thunder and lightning. A thick cloud covered the mountain, a loud trumpet blast was heard, and everyone in camp trembled with fear.
19.17: Moses led them out of the camp to meet God, and they stood at the foot of the mountain.
19.18: Mount Sinai was covered with smoke because the LORD had come down in a flaming fire. Smoke poured out of the mountain just like a furnace, and the whole mountain shook.
19.19: The trumpet blew louder and louder. Moses spoke, and God answered him with thunder.
19.20: The LORD came down to the top of Mount Sinai and told Moses to meet him there.
19.21: Then he said, "Moses, go and warn the people not to cross the boundary that you set at the foot of the mountain. They must not cross it to come and look at me, because if they do, many of them will die.
19.22: Only the priests may come near me, and they must obey strict rules before I let them. If they don't, they will be punished."
19.23: Moses replied, "The people cannot come up the mountain. You warned us to stay away because it is holy."
19.24: Then the LORD told Moses, "Go down and bring Aaron back here with you. But the priests and people must not try to push their way through, or I will rush at them like a flood!"
19.25: After Moses had gone back down, he told the people what the LORD had said.

20.1: God said to the people of Israel:
20.2: I am the LORD your God, the one who brought you out of Egypt where you were slaves.
20.3: Do not worship any god except me.
20.4: Do not make idols that look like anything in the sky or on earth or in the ocean under the earth.
20.5: Don't bow down and worship idols. I am the LORD your God, and I demand all your love. If you reject me, I will punish your families for three or four generations.
20.6: But if you love me and obey my laws, I will be kind to your families for thousands of generations.
20.7: Do not misuse my name. I am the LORD your God, and I will punish anyone who misuses my name.
20.8: Remember that the Sabbath Day belongs to me.
20.9: You have six days when you can do your work,
20.10: but the seventh day of each week belongs to me, your God. No one is to work on that day--not you, your children, your slaves, your animals, or the foreigners who live in your towns.
20.11: In six days I made the sky, the earth, the oceans, and everything in them, but on the seventh day I rested. That's why I made the Sabbath a special day that belongs to me.
20.12: Respect your father and your mother, and you will live a long time in the land I am giving you.
20.16: Do not tell lies about others.
20.17: Do not desire to possess anything that belongs to another person--not a house, a wife, a husband, a slave, an ox, a donkey, or anything else.
20.18: The people trembled with fear when they heard the thunder and the trumpet and saw the lightning and the smoke coming from the mountain. They stood a long way off
20.19: and said to Moses, "If you speak to us, we will listen. But don't let God speak to us, or we will die!"
20.20: "Don't be afraid!" Moses replied. "God has come only to test you, so that by obeying him you won't sin."
20.21: But when Moses went near the thick cloud where God was, the people stayed a long way off.
20.22: The LORD told Moses to say to the people of Israel: With your own eyes you saw me speak to you from heaven.
20.23: So you must never make idols of silver or gold to worship in place of me.
20.24: Build an altar out of earth, and offer on it your sacrifices of sheep, goats, and cattle. Wherever I choose to be worshiped, I will come down to bless you.
20.25: If you ever build an altar for me out of stones, do not use any tools to chisel the stones, because that would make the altar unfit for use in worship.
20.26: And don't build an altar that requires steps; you might expose yourself when you climb up.

21.1: The LORD gave Moses the following laws for his people:
21.2: If you buy a Hebrew slave, he must remain your slave for six years. But in the seventh year you must set him free, without cost to him.
21.3: If he was single at the time you bought him, he alone must be set free. But if he was married at the time, both he and his wife must be given their freedom.
21.4: If you give him a wife, and they have children, only the man himself must be set free; his wife and children remain the property of his owner.
21.5: But suppose the slave loves his wife and children and his owner so much that he won't leave them.
21.6: Then he must stand beside either the door or the doorpost at the place of worship, while his owner punches a small hole through one of his ears with a sharp metal rod. This makes him a slave for life.
21.7: A young woman who was sold by her father doesn't gain her freedom in the same way that a man does.
21.8: If she doesn't please the man who bought her to be his wife, he must let her be bought back. He cannot sell her to foreigners; this would break the contract he made with her.
21.9: If he selects her as a wife for his son, he must treat her as his own daughter.
21.10: If the man later marries another woman, he must continue to provide food and clothing for the one he bought and to treat her as a wife.
21.11: If he fails to do any of these things, she must be given her freedom without paying for it.
21.12: Death is the punishment for murder.
21.13: But if you did not intend to kill someone, and I, the LORD, let it happen anyway, you may run for safety to a place that I have set aside.
21.14: If you plan in advance to murder someone, there's no escape, not even by holding on to my altar. You will be dragged off and killed.
21.15: Death is the punishment for attacking your father or mother.
21.16: Death is the punishment for kidnapping. If you sell the person you kidnapped, or if you are caught with that person, the penalty is death.
21.17: Death is the punishment for cursing your father or mother.
21.18: Suppose two of you are arguing, and you hit the other with either a rock or your fist, without causing a fatal injury. If the victim has to stay in bed,
21.19: and later has to use a stick when walking outside, you must pay for the loss of time and do what you can to help until the injury is completely healed. That's your only responsibility.
21.20: Death is the punishment for beating to death any of your slaves.
21.21: However, if the slave lives a few days after the beating, you are not to be punished. After all, you have already lost the services of that slave who was your property.
21.22: Suppose a pregnant woman suffers a miscarriage as the result of an injury caused by someone who is fighting. If she isn't badly hurt, the one who injured her must pay whatever fine her husband demands and the judges approve.
21.23: But if she is seriously injured, the payment will be life for life,
21.24: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
21.25: burn for burn, cut for cut, and bruise for bruise.
21.26: If you hit one of your slaves and cause the loss of an eye, the slave must be set free.
21.27: The same law applies if you knock out a slave's tooth--the slave goes free.
21.28: A bull that kills someone with its horns must be killed and its meat destroyed, but the owner of the bull isn't responsible for the death.
21.29: Suppose you own a bull that has been in the habit of attacking people, but you have refused to keep it fenced in. If that bull kills someone, both you and the bull must be put to death by stoning.
21.30: However, you may save your own life by paying whatever fine is demanded.
21.31: This same law applies if the bull gores someone's son or daughter.
21.32: If the bull kills a slave, you must pay the slave owner 30 pieces of silver for the loss of the slave, and the bull must be killed by stoning.
21.33: Suppose someone's ox or donkey is killed by falling into an open pit that you dug or left uncovered on your property.
21.34: You must pay for the dead animal, and it becomes yours.
21.35: If your bull kills someone else's, yours must be sold. Then the money from your bull and the meat from the dead bull must be divided equally between you and the other owner.
21.36: If you refuse to fence in a bull that is known to attack others, you must replace any animal it kills, but the dead animal will belong to you.

22.1: If you steal an ox and slaughter or sell it, you must replace it with five oxen; if you steal a sheep and slaughter it or sell it, you must replace it with four sheep.
22.5: If you allow any of your animals to stray from your property and graze in someone else's field or vineyard, you must repay the damage from the best part of your own harvest of grapes and grain.
22.6: If you carelessly let a fire spread from your property to someone else's, you must pay the owner for any crops or fields destroyed by the fire.
22.7: Suppose a neighbor asks you to keep some silver or other valuables, and they are stolen from your house. If the thief is caught, the thief must repay double.
22.8: But if the thief isn't caught, some judges will decide if you are the guilty one.
22.9: Suppose two people claim to own the same ox or donkey or sheep or piece of clothing. Then the judges must decide the case, and the guilty person will pay the owner double.
22.10: Suppose a neighbor who is going to be away asks you to keep a donkey or an ox or a sheep or some other animal, and it dies or gets injured or is stolen while no one is looking.
22.11: If you swear with me as your witness that you did not harm the animal, you do not have to replace it. Your word is enough.
22.12: But if the animal was stolen while in your care, you must replace it.
22.13: If the animal was attacked and killed by a wild animal, and you can show the remains of the dead animal to its owner, you do not have to replace it.
22.14: Suppose you borrow an animal from a neighbor, and it gets injured or dies while the neighbor isn't around. Then you must replace it.
22.15: But if something happens to the animal while the owner is present, you do not have to replace it. If you had leased the animal, the money you paid the owner will cover any harm done to it.
22.16: Suppose a young woman has never had sex and isn't engaged. If a man talks her into having sex, he must pay the bride price and marry her.
22.17: But if her father refuses to let her marry the man, the bride price must still be paid.
22.18: Death is the punishment for witchcraft.
22.19: Death is the punishment for having sex with an animal.
22.20: Death is the punishment for offering sacrifices to any god except me.
22.21: Do not mistreat or abuse foreigners who live among you. Remember, you were foreigners in Egypt.
22.22: Do not mistreat widows or orphans.
22.23: If you do, they will beg for my help, and I will come to their rescue.
22.24: In fact, I will get so angry that I will kill your men and make widows of their wives and orphans of their children.
22.25: Don't charge interest when you lend money to any of my people who are in need.
22.26: Before sunset you must return any coat taken as security for a loan,
22.27: because that is the only cover the poor have when they sleep at night. I am a merciful God, and when they call out to me, I will come to help them.
22.28: Don't speak evil of me or of the ruler of your people.
22.29: Don't fail to give me the offerings of grain and wine that belong to me. Dedicate to me your first-born sons
22.30: and the first-born of your cattle and sheep. Let the animals stay with their mothers for seven days, then on the eighth day give them to me, your God.
22.31: You are my chosen people, so don't eat the meat of any of your livestock that was killed by a wild animal. Instead, feed the meat to dogs.

23.1: Don't spread harmful rumors or help a criminal by giving false evidence.
23.2: Always tell the truth in court, even if everyone else is dishonest and stands in the way of justice.
23.3: And don't favor the poor, simply because they are poor.
23.4: If you find an ox or a donkey that has wandered off, take it back where it belongs, even if the owner is your enemy.
23.5: If a donkey is overloaded and falls down, you must do what you can to help, even if it belongs to someone who doesn't like you.
23.6: Make sure that the poor are given equal justice in court.
23.7: Don't bring false charges against anyone or sentence an innocent person to death. I won't forgive you if you do.
23.8: Don't accept bribes. Judges are blinded and justice is twisted by bribes.
23.9: Don't mistreat foreigners. You were foreigners in Egypt, and you know what it is like.
23.10: Plant and harvest your crops for six years,
23.11: but let the land rest during the seventh year. The poor are to eat what they want from your fields, vineyards, and olive trees during that year, and when they have all they want from your fields, leave the rest for wild animals.
23.12: Work the first six days of the week, but rest and relax on the seventh day. This law is not only for you, but for your oxen, donkeys, and slaves, as well as for any foreigners among you.
23.13: Make certain that you obey everything I have said. Don't pray to other gods or even mention their names.
23.14: Celebrate three festivals each year in my honor.
23.15: Celebrate the Festival of Thin Bread by eating bread made without yeast, just as I have commanded. Do this at the proper time during the month of Abib, because it is the month when you left Egypt. And make certain that everyone brings the proper offerings.
23.16: Celebrate the Harvest Festival each spring when you start harvesting your wheat, and celebrate the Festival of Shelters each autumn when you pick your fruit.
23.17: Your men must come to these three festivals each year to worship me.
23.18: Do not offer bread made with yeast when you sacrifice an animal to me. And make sure that the fat of the animal is burned that same day.
23.19: Each year bring the best part of your first harvest to the place of worship. Don't boil a young goat in its mother's milk.
23.20: I am sending an angel to protect you and to lead you into the land I have ready for you.
23.21: Carefully obey everything the angel says, because I am giving him complete authority, and he won't tolerate rebellion.
23.22: If you faithfully obey him, I will be a fierce enemy of your enemies.
23.23: My angel will lead you into the land of the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Canaanites, Hivites, and Jebusites, and I will wipe them out.
23.24: Don't worship their gods or follow their customs. Instead, destroy their idols and shatter their stone images.
23.25: Worship only me, the LORD your God! I will bless you with plenty of food and water and keep you strong.
23.26: Your women will give birth to healthy children, and everyone will live a long life.
23.27: I will terrify those nations and make your enemies so confused that they will run from you.
23.28: I will make the Hivites, Canaanites, and Hittites panic as you approach.
23.29: But I won't do all this in the first year, because the land would become poor, and wild animals would be everywhere.
23.30: Instead, I will force out your enemies little by little and give your nation time to grow strong enough to take over the land.
23.31: I will see that your borders reach from the Red Sea to the Euphrates River and from the Mediterranean Sea to the desert. I will let you defeat the people who live there, and you will force them out of the land.
23.32: But you must not make any agreements with them or with their gods.
23.33: Don't let them stay in your land. They will trap you into sinning against me and worshiping their gods.

24.1: The LORD said to Moses, "Come up to me on this mountain. Bring along Aaron, as well as his two sons Nadab and Abihu, and 70 of Israel's leaders. They must worship me at a distance,
24.2: but you are to come near. Don't let anyone else come up."
24.3: Moses gave the LORD's instructions to the people, and they all promised, "We will do everything the LORD has commanded!"
24.4: Then Moses wrote down what the LORD had said. The next morning Moses got up early. He built an altar at the foot of the mountain and set up a large stone for each of the twelve tribes of Israel.
24.5: He also sent some young men to burn offerings and to sacrifice bulls as special offerings to the LORD.
24.6: Moses put half of the blood from the animals into bowls and sprinkled the rest on the altar.
24.7: Then he read aloud the LORD's commands and promises, and the people shouted, "We will obey the LORD and do everything he has commanded!"
24.8: Moses took the blood from the bowls and sprinkled it on the people. Next, he told them, "With this blood the LORD makes his agreement with you."
24.9: Moses and Aaron, together with Nadab and Abihu and the 70 leaders, went up the mountain
24.10: and saw the God of Israel. Under his feet was something that looked like a pavement made out of sapphire, and it was as bright as the sky.
24.11: Even though these leaders of Israel saw God, he did not punish them. So they ate and drank.
24.12: The LORD said to Moses, "Come up on the mountain and stay here for a while. I will give you the two flat stones on which I have written the laws that my people must obey."
24.13: Moses and Joshua his assistant got ready, then Moses started up the mountain to meet with God.
24.14: Moses had told the leaders, "Wait here until we come back. Aaron and Hur will be with you, and they can settle any arguments while we are away."
24.15: When Moses went up on Mount Sinai, a cloud covered it,
24.16: and the bright glory of the LORD came down and stayed there. The cloud covered the mountain for six days, and on the seventh day the LORD told Moses to come into the cloud.

25.2: Tell everyone in Israel who wants to give gifts that they must bring them to you.
25.3: Here is a list of what you are to collect: Gold, silver, and bronze;
25.4: blue, purple, and red wool; fine linen; goat hair;
25.5: tanned ram skins; fine leather; acacia wood;
25.6: olive oil for the lamp; sweet-smelling spices to mix with the incense and with the oil for dedicating the tent and ordaining the priests;
25.7: and onyx stones and other gems for the sacred vest and the breastpiece.
25.8: I also want them to build a special place where I can live among my people.
25.9: Make it and its furnishings exactly like the pattern I will show you.
25.10: Tell the people to build a chest of acacia wood 110 centimeters long, 66 centimeters wide, and 66 centimeters high.
25.11: Cover it inside and out with pure gold and put a gold edging around the lid.
25.12: Make four gold rings and attach one of them to each of the four legs of the chest.
25.13: Make two poles of acacia wood. Cover them with gold
25.14: and put them through the rings, so the chest can be carried by the poles.
25.15: Don't ever remove the poles from the rings.
25.16: When I give you the Ten Commandments written on two flat stones, put them inside the chest.
25.17: Make the lid of the chest out of pure gold.
25.20: The creatures must face each other with their wings spread over the chest.
25.21: Inside it place the two flat stones with the Ten Commandments on them and put the gold lid on top of the chest.
25.22: I will meet you there between the two creatures and tell you what my people must do and what they must not do.
25.23: Make a table of acacia wood 88 centimeters long, 44 centimeters wide, and 66 centimeters high.
25.26: Make four gold rings and attach one to each of the legs
25.31: Make a lampstand of pure gold. The whole lampstand, including its decorative flowers, must be made from a single piece of hammered gold
25.32: with three branches on each of its two sides.
25.33: There are to be three decorative almond blossoms on each branch
25.35: There must also be a blossom where each pair of branches comes out from the stem.
25.36: The lampstand, including its branches and decorative flowers, must be made from a single piece of hammered pure gold.
25.37: The lamp on the top and those at the end of each of its six branches must be made so as to shine toward the front of the lampstand.
25.38: The tongs and trays for taking care of the lamps are to be made of pure gold.
25.39: The lampstand and its equipment will require 35 kilograms of pure gold,
25.40: and they must be made according to the pattern I showed you on the mountain.

26.1: The top of the sacred tent must be made from ten pieces of the finest linen, woven with blue, purple, and red wool and embroidered with figures of winged creatures.
26.2: Make each piece twelve meters long and two meters wide
26.3: and sew them together into two panels with five sections each.
26.9: Sew five of the sections together to make one panel. Then sew the other six together to make a second panel, and fold the sixth section double over the front of the tent.
26.10: Put 50 loops along one of the wider sides of each panel
26.11: and fasten the two panels at the loops with 50 bronze hooks.
26.14: Make two more coverings--one with tanned ram skins and the other with fine leather.
26.15: Build a framework of acacia wood for the walls of the sacred tent.
26.16: Make each frame 4 meters high and 66 centimeters wide
26.17: with two wooden pegs near the bottom.
26.22: For the back wall along the west side use six frames
26.25: Altogether, this back wall will have eight frames with two silver stands under each one.
26.28: with the center crossbar running the full length of the wall.
26.29: Cover the frames and the crossbars with gold and attach gold rings to the frames to run the crossbars through.
26.30: Then set up the tent in the way I showed you on the mountain.
26.34: Inside the most holy place, put the sacred chest that has the place of mercy on its lid.
26.35: Outside the most holy place, as you face the curtain, put the table for the sacred bread on the right side and the gold lampstand on the left.
26.36: For the entrance to the tent, use a piece of fine linen woven with blue, purple, and red wool and embroidered with fancy needlework.
26.37: Cover five acacia wood posts with gold and set them each on a bronze stand. Then put gold hooks on the posts and hang the curtain there.

27.1: Use acacia wood to build an altar 2.25 meters square and 1.34 meters high,
27.2: and make each of the four top corners stick up like the horn of a bull. Then cover the whole altar with bronze, including the four horns.
27.3: All the equipment for the altar must also be made of bronze--the pans for the hot ashes, the shovels, the sprinkling bowls, the meat forks, and the fire pans.
27.8: Construct the altar in the shape of an open box, just as you were shown on the mountain.
27.16: Use four more of these posts for the entrance way, then hang on them an embroidered curtain of fine linen nine meters long and woven with blue, purple, and red wool.
27.19: Make the rest of the equipment for the sacred tent of bronze, including the pegs for the tent and for the curtain surrounding the courtyard.
27.20: Command the people of Israel to supply you with the purest olive oil. Do this so the lamp will keep burning
27.21: in front of the curtain that separates the holy place from the most holy place, where the sacred chest is kept. Aaron and his sons are responsible for keeping the lamp burning every night in the sacred tent. The Israelites must always obey this command.

28.1: Send for your brother Aaron and his sons Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar. They are the ones I have chosen from Israel to serve as my priests.
28.2: Make Aaron some beautiful clothes that are worthy of a high priest.
28.3: Aaron is to be dedicated as my high priest, and his clothes must be made only by persons who possess skills that I have given them.
28.4: Here are the items that need to be made: a breastpiece, a priestly vest, a robe, an embroidered shirt, a turban, and a sash. These sacred clothes are to be made for your brother Aaron and his sons who will be my priests.
28.5: Use only gold and fine linen, woven with blue, purple, and red wool, for making these clothes.
28.15: From the same costly material make a breastpiece for the high priest to use in finding out what I want my people to do.
28.16: It is to be 22 centimeters square and folded double
28.17: with four rows of three precious stones: In the first row put a carnelian, a chrysolite, and an emerald;
28.18: in the second row a turquoise, a sapphire, and a diamond;
28.19: in the third row a jacinth, an agate, and an amethyst;
28.20: and in the fourth row a beryl, an onyx, and a jasper. Mount the stones in delicate gold settings
28.21: and engrave on each of them the name of one of the twelve tribes of Israel.
28.26: Attach two other gold rings to the lower inside corners next to the vest
28.27: and two more near the bottom of the shoulder straps right above the sash.
28.28: Then take a blue cord and tie the two lower rings on the breastpiece to those on the vest. This will keep the breastpiece in place.
28.29: In this way Aaron will have the names of the twelve tribes of Israel written on his heart each time he enters the holy place, and I will never forget my people.
28.30: He must also wear on his breastpiece the two small objects that he uses to receive answers from me.
28.31: Under his vest Aaron must wear a robe of blue wool
28.32: with an opening in the center for his head. Be sure to bind the material around the collar to keep it from wearing out.
28.35: If Aaron wears these clothes when he enters the holy place as my high priest, the sound of the bells will be heard, and his life will not be in danger.
28.36: On a narrow strip of pure gold engrave the words: "Dedicated to the LORD."
28.37: Fasten it to the front of Aaron's turban with a blue cord,
28.38: so he can wear it on his forehead. This will show that he will take on himself the guilt for any sins the people of Israel commit in offering their gifts to me, and I will forgive them.
28.39: Make Aaron's robe and turban of fine linen and decorate his sash with fancy needlework.
28.40: Since Aaron's sons are priests, they should also look dignified. So make robes, sashes, and special caps for them.
28.41: Then dress Aaron and his sons in these clothes, pour olive oil on their heads, and ordain them as my priests.
28.42: Make linen shorts for them that reach from the waist down to the thigh, so they won't expose themselves.
28.43: Whenever they enter the sacred tent or serve at the altar or enter the holy place, they must wear these shorts, or else they will be guilty and die. This same rule applies to any of their descendants who serve as priests.

29.1: When you ordain Aaron and his sons to serve me as priests, choose a young bull and two rams that have nothing wrong with them.
29.2: Then from your finest flour make three batches of dough without yeast. Shape some of it into larger loaves, some into smaller loaves mixed with olive oil, and the rest into thin wafers brushed with oil.
29.3: Put all of this bread in a basket and bring it when you come to sacrifice the three animals to me.
29.4: Bring Aaron and his sons to the entrance of the sacred tent and tell them to wash themselves.
29.5: Dress Aaron in the priestly shirt, the robe that goes under the sacred vest, the vest itself, the breastpiece, and the sash.
29.6: Put on his turban with its narrow strip of engraved gold
29.7: and then ordain him by pouring olive oil on his head.
29.8: Next, dress Aaron's sons in their special shirts,
29.9: caps, and sashes, then ordain them, because they and their descendants will always be priests.
29.10: Lead the bull to the entrance of the sacred tent, where Aaron and his sons will lay their hands on its head.
29.11: Kill the bull near my altar in front of the tent.
29.12: Use a finger to smear some of its blood on each of the four corners of the altar and pour out the rest of the blood on the ground next to the altar.
29.13: Then take the fat from the animal's insides, as well as the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat, and send them up as an offering to me in the smoke from the altar.
29.14: But the meat, the skin, and the food still in the bull's stomach must be burned outside the camp as an offering to ask forgiveness for the sins of the priests.
29.15: Bring one of the rams to Aaron and his sons and tell them to lay their hands on its head.
29.16: Kill the ram and splatter its blood against all four sides of the altar.
29.17: Cut up the ram, wash its insides and legs, and lay all of its parts on the altar, including the head.
29.18: Then make sure that the whole animal goes up in smoke with a smell that pleases me.
29.19: Bring the other ram to Aaron and his sons and tell them to lay their hands on its head.
29.20: Kill the ram and place some of its blood on Aaron's right ear lobe, his right thumb, and the big toe of his right foot. Do the same for each of his sons and splatter the rest of the blood against the four sides of the altar.

32.1: After the people saw that Moses had been on the mountain for a long time, they went to Aaron and said, "Make us an image of a god who will lead and protect us. Moses brought us out of Egypt, but nobody knows what has happened to him."

32.4: then he melted them and made an idol in the shape of a young bull. All the people said to one another, "This is the god who brought us out of Egypt!"
32.5: When Aaron saw what was happening, he built an altar in front of the idol and said, "Tomorrow we will celebrate in honor of the LORD."
32.6: The people got up early the next morning and killed some animals to be used for sacrifices and others to be eaten. Then everyone ate and drank so much that they began to carry on like wild people.
32.7: The LORD said to Moses: Hurry back down! Those people you led out of Egypt are acting like fools.

32.13: Remember the solemn promise you made to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. You promised that someday they would have as many descendants as there are stars in the sky and that you would give them land.

32.30: The next day Moses told the people, "This is a terrible thing you have done. But I will go back to the LORD to see if I can do something to keep this sin from being held against you."

34.1: One day the LORD said to Moses, "Cut two flat stones like the first ones I made, and I will write on them the same commandments that were on the two you broke.

34.4: So Moses cut two flat stones like the first ones, and early the next morning he carried them to the top of Mount Sinai, just as the LORD had commanded.
34.5: The LORD God came down in a cloud and stood beside Moses there on the mountain. God spoke his holy name, "the LORD."
34.6: Then he passed in front of Moses and called out, "I am the LORD God. I am merciful and very patient with my people. I show great love, and I can be trusted.
34.7: I keep my promises to my people forever, but I also punish anyone who sins. When people sin, I punish them and their children, and also their grandchildren and great-grandchildren."
34.8: Moses quickly bowed down to the ground and worshiped the LORD.
34.9: He prayed, "LORD, if you really are pleased with me, I pray that you will go with us. It is true that these people are sinful and rebellious, but forgive our sin and let us be your people."
34.10: The LORD said: I promise to perform miracles for you that have never been seen anywhere on earth. Neighboring nations will stand in fear and know that I was the one who did these marvelous things.
34.11: I will force out the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, but you must do what I command you today.
34.12: Don't make treaties with any of those people. If you do, it will be like falling into a trap.
34.13: Instead, you must destroy their altars and tear down the sacred poles they use in the worship of the goddess Asherah.
34.14: I demand your complete loyalty--you must not worship any other god!
34.15: Don't make treaties with the people there, or you will soon find yourselves worshiping their gods and taking part in their sacrificial meals.
34.16: Your men will even marry their women and be influenced to worship their gods.
34.17: Don't make metal images of gods.
34.18: Don't fail to observe the Festival of Thin Bread in the month of Abib. Obey me and eat bread without yeast for seven days during Abib, because that is the month you left Egypt.
34.19: The first-born males of your families and of your flocks and herds belong to me.
34.20: You can save the life of a first-born donkey by sacrificing a lamb; if you don't, you must break the donkey's neck. You must save every first-born son. Bring an offering every time you come to worship.
34.21: Work for six days and rest on the seventh day, even during the seasons for plowing and harvesting.
34.22: Celebrate the Harvest Festival each spring when you start harvesting your wheat, and celebrate the Festival of Shelters each autumn when you pick your fruit.
34.23: Your men must come to worship me three times a year, because I am the LORD God of Israel.
34.24: As you advance, I will force the nations out of your land and enlarge your borders. Then no one will try to take your property when you come to worship me these three times each year.
34.25: When you sacrifice an animal on the altar, don't offer bread made with yeast. And don't save any part of the Passover meal for the next day.
34.26: I am the LORD your God, and you must bring the first part of your harvest to the place of worship. Don't boil a young goat in its mother's milk.
34.27: The LORD told Moses to put these laws in writing, as part of his agreement with Israel.
34.28: Moses stayed on the mountain with the LORD for 40 days and nights, without eating or drinking. And he wrote down the Ten Commandments, the most important part of God's agreement with his people.
34.29: Moses came down from Mount Sinai, carrying the Ten Commandments. His face was shining brightly because the LORD had been speaking to him. But Moses did not know at first that his face was shining.

34.31: Moses called out for Aaron and the leaders to come to him, and he spoke with them.
34.32: Then the rest of the people of Israel gathered around Moses, and he gave them the laws that the LORD had given him on Mount Sinai.

34.35: They could see that his face was still shining. So after he had spoken with them, he would put the veil back on and leave it on until the next time he went to speak with the LORD.

40.28: The curtain was hung at the entrance to the sacred tent.

40.37: then they would set up camp and stay there, until it moved again.

1.4: Lay your hand on its head, and I will accept the animal as a sacrifice for taking away your sins.

2.1: When you offer sacrifices to give thanks to me, you must use only your finest flour. Put it in a dish, sprinkle olive oil and incense on the flour,
2.2: and take it to the priests from Aaron's family. One of them will scoop up the incense together with a handful of the flour and oil. Then, to show that the whole offering belongs to me, the priest will lay this part on the bronze altar and send it up in smoke with a smell that pleases me.
2.3: The rest of this sacrifice is for the priests; it is very holy because it was offered to me.
2.4: If you bake bread in an oven for this sacrifice, use only your finest flour, but without any yeast. You may make the flour into a loaf mixed with olive oil, or you may make it into thin wafers and brush them with oil.
2.5: If you cook bread in a shallow pan for this sacrifice, use only your finest flour. Mix it with olive oil, but do not use any yeast.
2.6: Then break the bread into small pieces and sprinkle them with oil.
2.7: If you cook your bread in a pan with a lid on it, you must also use the finest flour mixed with oil.
2.8: You may prepare sacrifices to give thanks in any of these three ways. Bring your sacrifice to a priest, and he will take it to the bronze altar.
2.9: Then, to show that the whole offering belongs to me, the priest will lay part of it on the altar and send it up in smoke with a smell that pleases me.
2.10: The rest of this sacrifice is for the priests; it is very holy because it was offered to me.
2.11: Yeast and honey must never be burned on the altar, so don't ever mix either of these in a grain sacrifice.
2.12: You may offer either of them separately, when you present the first part of your harvest to me, but they must never be burned on the altar.
2.13: Salt is offered when you make an agreement with me, so sprinkle salt on these sacrifices.
2.14: Freshly cut grain, either roasted or coarsely ground, must be used when you offer the first part of your grain harvest.
2.15: You must mix in some olive oil and put incense on top, because this is a grain sacrifice.
2.16: A priest will sprinkle all of the incense and some of the grain and oil on the altar and send them up in smoke to show that the whole offering belongs to me.

3.1: When you offer sacrifices to ask my blessing, you may offer either a bull or a cow, but there must be nothing wrong with the animal.
3.2: Lead it to the entrance of the sacred tent, lay your hand on its head, and have it killed there. A priest from Aaron's family will splatter its blood against the four sides of the altar.
3.3: Offer all of the fat on the animal's insides,
3.4: as well as the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat.
3.5: Some of the priests will lay these pieces on the altar and send them up in smoke with a smell that pleases me, together with the sacrifice that is offered to please me.
3.6: Instead of a bull or a cow, you may offer any sheep or goat that has nothing wrong with it.
3.7: If you offer a sheep, you must present it to me at the entrance to the sacred tent.
3.8: Lay your hand on its head and have it killed there. A priest will then splatter its blood against the four sides of the altar.
3.9: Offer the fat on the tail, the tailbone, and the insides,
3.10: as well as the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat.
3.11: One of the priests will lay these pieces on the altar and send them up in smoke as a food offering for me.
3.12: If you offer a goat, you must also present it to me
3.13: at the entrance to the sacred tent. Lay your hand on its head and have it killed there. A priest will then splatter its blood against the four sides of the altar.
3.14: Offer all of the fat on the animal's insides,
3.15: as well as the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat.
3.16: One of the priests will put these pieces on the altar and send them up in smoke as a food offering with a smell that pleases me. All fat belongs to me.
3.17: So you and your descendants must never eat any fat or any blood, not even in the privacy of your own homes. This law will never change.

4.2: to say to the community of Israel: Offer a sacrifice to ask forgiveness when you sin by accidentally doing something I have told you not to do.
4.3: When the high priest sins, he makes everyone else guilty too. And so, he must sacrifice a young bull that has nothing wrong with it.
4.4: The priest will lead the bull to the entrance of the sacred tent, lay his hand on its head, and kill it there.
4.5: He will take a bowl of the blood inside the tent,
4.6: dip a finger in the blood, and sprinkle some of it seven times toward the sacred chest behind the curtain.
4.7: Then, in my presence, he will smear some of the blood on each of the four corners of the incense altar, before pouring out the rest at the foot of the bronze altar near the entrance to the tent.
4.13: When the nation of Israel disobeys me without meaning to, the whole nation is still guilty.
4.14: Once you realize what has happened, you must sacrifice a young bull to ask my forgiveness. Lead the bull to the entrance of the sacred tent,
4.15: where your tribal leaders will lay their hands on its head, before having it killed in my presence.
4.16: The priest will take a bowl of the animal's blood inside the sacred tent,
4.17: dip a finger in the blood, and sprinkle some of it seven times toward the sacred chest behind the curtain.
4.18: Then, in my presence, he must smear some of the blood on each of the four corners of the incense altar, before pouring out the rest at the foot of the bronze altar near the entrance to the tent.
4.22: Any tribal leader who disobeys me without knowing it is still guilty.
4.23: As soon as the leader realizes what has happened, he must sacrifice a goat that has nothing wrong with it.
4.24: This is a sacrifice for sin. So he will lay his hand on the animal's head, before having it killed in my presence at the north side of the bronze altar.
4.25: The priest will dip a finger in the blood, smear some of it on each of the four corners of the altar, and pour out the rest at the foot of the altar.
4.26: Then he must send all of the fat up in smoke, just as he does when a sacrifice is offered to ask my blessing. By this sacrifice the leader's sin will be forgiven.
4.27: When any of you ordinary people disobey me without meaning to, you are still guilty.
4.28: As soon as you realize what you have done, you must sacrifice a female goat that has nothing wrong with it.
4.29: Lead the goat to the north side of the bronze altar and lay your hand on its head, before having it killed.
4.30: Then a priest will dip a finger in the blood; he will smear some of it on each of the four corners of the altar and pour out the rest at the foot of the altar.
4.31: After this, the priest will remove all of the fat, just as he does when an animal is sacrificed to ask my blessing. The priest will then send the fat up in smoke with a smell that pleases me. This animal is sacrificed so that I will forgive you ordinary people when you sin.
4.32: If you offer a lamb instead of a goat as a sacrifice for sin, it must be a female that has nothing wrong with it.
4.33: Lead the lamb to the altar and lay your hand on its head, before having it killed.
4.34: The priest will dip a finger in the blood, smear some of it on each of the four corners of the altar, and pour out the rest at the foot of the altar.
4.35: After this, all of the fat must be removed, just as when an animal is sacrificed to ask my blessing. Then the priest will send it up in smoke to me, together with a food offering, and your sin will be forgiven.

5.1: If you refuse to testify in court about something you saw or know has happened, you have sinned and can be punished.
5.2: You are guilty and unfit to worship me, if you accidentally touch the dead body of any kind of unclean animal.
5.3: You are guilty if you find out that you have accidentally touched anything unclean that comes from a human body.
5.4: You are guilty the moment you realize that you have made a hasty promise to do something good or bad.
5.5: As soon as you discover that you have committed any of these sins, you must confess what you have done.
5.6: Then you must bring a female sheep or goat to me as the price for your sin. A priest will sacrifice the animal, and you will be forgiven.
5.7: If you are poor and cannot afford to bring an animal, you may bring two doves or two pigeons. One of these will be a sacrifice to ask my forgiveness, and the other will be a sacrifice to please me.
5.8: Give both birds to the priest, who will offer one as a sacrifice to ask my forgiveness. He will wring its neck without tearing off its head,
5.9: splatter some of its blood on one side of the bronze altar, and drain out the rest at the foot of the altar.
5.10: Then he will follow the proper rules for offering the other bird as a sacrifice to please me. You will be forgiven when the priest offers these sacrifices as the price for your sin.
5.11: If you are so poor that you cannot afford doves or pigeons, you may bring one kilogram of your finest flour. This is a sacrifice to ask my forgiveness, so don't sprinkle olive oil or sweet-smelling incense on it.
5.12: Give the flour to a priest, who will scoop up a handful and send it up in smoke together with the other offerings. This is a reminder that all of the flour belongs to me.
5.13: By offering this sacrifice, the priest pays the price for any of these sins you may have committed. The priest gets to keep the rest of the flour, just as he does with grain sacrifices.
5.16: In addition, you must pay what you owe plus a fine of 20 percent. Then the priest will offer the ram as a sacrifice to make things right, and you will be forgiven.

6.4: When this happens, you must return what doesn't belong to you
6.5: and pay the owner a fine of 20 percent.
6.10: The next morning you will dress in your priestly clothes, including your linen underwear. Then clean away the ashes left by the sacrifices and pile them beside the altar.
6.11: Change into your everyday clothes, take the ashes outside the camp, and pile them in the special place.
6.12: The fire must never go out, so put wood on it each morning. After this, you are to lay an animal on the altar next to the fat that you sacrifice to ask my blessing. Then send it all up in smoke to me.

6.14: When someone offers a sacrifice to give thanks to me, the priests from Aaron's family must bring it to the front of the bronze altar,
6.15: where one of them will scoop up a handful of the flour and oil, together with all the incense on it. Then, to show that the whole offering belongs to me, he will lay all of this on the altar and send it up in smoke with a smell that pleases me.
6.18: Only the men in Aaron's family are allowed to eat this bread, and they must go through a ceremony to be made holy before touching it. This law will never change.
6.20: and told him what sacrifices the priests must offer on the morning and evening of the day they are ordained: It is the same as the regular morning and evening sacrifices--half a kilogram of flour
6.21: mixed with olive oil and cooked in a shallow pan. The bread must then be crumbled into small pieces and sent up in smoke with a smell that pleases me.
6.25: how the priests from Aaron's family were to offer the sacrifice for sin: This sacrifice is very sacred, and the animal must be killed in my presence at the north side of the bronze altar.
6.26: The priest who offers this sacrifice must eat it in the sacred courtyard of the sacred tent,
6.27: and anyone or anything that touches the meat will be holy. If any of the animal's blood is splattered on the clothes of the priest, they must be washed in a holy place.
6.28: If the meat was cooked in a clay pot, the pot must be destroyed, but if it was cooked in a bronze pot, the pot must be scrubbed and rinsed with water.
6.29: This sacrifice is very holy, and only the priests may have any part of it.
