7.1: The sacrifice to make things right is very sacred.
7.2: The animal must be killed in the same place where the sacrifice to please me is killed, and the animal's blood must be splattered against the four sides of the bronze altar.
7.3: Offer all of the animal's fat, including the fat on its tail and on its insides,
7.4: as well as the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat.
7.5: One of the priests will lay these pieces on the altar and send them up in smoke to me.
7.6: This sacrifice for making things right is very holy. Only the priests may eat it, and they must eat it in a holy place.
7.7: The ceremony for this sacrifice and the one for sin are the same, and the meat may be eaten only by the priest who performs this ceremony of forgiveness.
7.8: In fact, the priest who offers a sacrifice to please me may keep the skin of the animal,
7.9: just as he may eat the bread from a sacrifice to give thanks to me.
7.10: All other grain sacrifices--with or without olive oil in them--are to be divided equally among the priests of Aaron's family.
7.11: Here are the instructions for offering a sacrifice to ask my blessing:
7.12: If you offer it to give thanks, you must offer some bread together with it. Use the finest flour to make three kinds of bread without yeast--two in the form of loaves mixed with olive oil and one in the form of thin wafers brushed with oil.
7.13: You must also make some bread with yeast.
7.14: Give me one loaf or wafer from each of these four kinds of bread, after which they will belong to the priest who splattered the blood against the bronze altar.
7.15: When you offer an animal to ask a blessing from me or to thank me, the meat belongs to you, but it must be eaten the same day.
7.16: It is different with the sacrifices you offer when you make me a promise or voluntarily give me something. The meat from those sacrifices may be kept and eaten the next day,
7.19: Don't eat any of the meat that has touched something unclean. Instead, burn it. The rest of the meat may be eaten by anyone who is clean and acceptable to me.
7.23: to say to the people: Don't eat the fat of cattle, sheep, or goats.
7.24: If one of your animals dies or is killed by some wild animal, you may do anything with its fat except eat it.
7.25: If you eat the fat of an animal that can be used as a sacrifice to me, you will no longer belong to the community of Israel.
7.26: And no matter where you live, you must not eat the blood of any bird or animal,
7.27: or you will no longer belong to the community of Israel.
7.31: A priest from Aaron's family will then send the fat up in smoke, but the ribs belong to the priests.
7.34: I have decided that the people of Israel must always give the choice ribs and the upper joint of the right hind leg to Aaron's descendants
7.35: who have been ordained as priests to serve me.
7.36: This law will never change. I am the LORD!
7.37: These are the ceremonies for sacrifices to please the LORD, to give him thanks, and to ask for his blessing or his forgiveness, as well as the ceremonies for those sacrifices that demand a payment and for the sacrifices that are offered when priests are ordained.
7.38: While Moses and the people of Israel were in the desert at Mount Sinai, the LORD commanded them to start offering these sacrifices.

8.2: Send for Aaron and his sons, as well as their priestly clothes, the oil for ordination, the bull for the sin offering, the two rams, and a basket of bread made without yeast.
8.3: Then bring the whole community of Israel together at the entrance to the sacred tent.
8.4: Moses obeyed the LORD, and when everyone had come together,
8.5: he said, "We are here to follow the LORD's instructions."
8.6: After Moses told Aaron and his sons to step forward, he told them to wash themselves.
8.7: He put the priestly shirt and robe on Aaron and wrapped the sash around his waist. Then he put the sacred vest on Aaron and fastened it with the finely woven belt.
8.8: Next, he put on Aaron the sacred breastpiece that was used in finding out what the LORD wanted his people to do.
8.9: He placed the turban on Aaron's head, and on the front of the turban was the narrow strip of thin gold as a sign of his dedication to the LORD.
8.10: Moses then dedicated the sacred tent and everything in it to the LORD by sprinkling them with some of the oil for ordination.
8.11: He sprinkled the bronze altar seven times, and he sprinkled its equipment, as well as the large bronze bowl and its base.
8.12: He also poured some of the oil on Aaron's head to dedicate him to the LORD.
8.13: Next, Moses dressed Aaron's sons in their shirts, then tied sashes around them and put special caps on them, just as the LORD had commanded.
8.14: Moses led out the bull that was to be sacrificed for sin, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head.
8.15: After it was killed, Moses dipped a finger in the blood and smeared some of it on each of the four corners of the bronze altar, before pouring out the rest at the foot of the altar. This purified the altar and made it a fit place for offering the sacrifice for sin.
8.16: Moses then took the fat on the bull's insides, as well as the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat, and sent them up in smoke on the altar fire.
8.17: Finally, he took the skin and the flesh of the bull, together with the food still in its stomach, and burned them outside the camp, just as the LORD had commanded.
8.18: Moses led out the ram for the sacrifice to please the LORD. After Aaron and his sons had laid their hands on its head,
8.19: Moses killed the ram and splattered its blood against the four sides of the altar.
8.22: Moses led out the ram for the ceremony of ordination. Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head,
8.23: and it was killed. Moses smeared some of its blood on Aaron's right earlobe, some on his right thumb, and some on the big toe of his right foot.
8.24: Moses did the same thing for Aaron's sons, before splattering the rest of the blood against the four sides of the altar.
8.25: He took the animal's fat tail, the fat on its insides, and the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat, and the right hind leg.
8.26: Then he took from a basket some of each of the three kinds of bread that had been made without yeast and had been dedicated to the LORD.
8.27: Moses placed the bread on top of the meat and gave it all to Aaron and his sons, who lifted it up to show that it was dedicated to the LORD.
8.28: After this, Moses placed it on the fires of the altar and sent it up in smoke with a smell that pleased the LORD. This was part of the ordination ceremony.
8.29: Moses lifted up the choice ribs of the ram to show that they were dedicated to the LORD. This was the part that the LORD had said Moses could have.
8.30: Finally, Moses sprinkled the priestly clothes of Aaron and his sons with some of the oil for ordination and with some of the blood from the altar. So Aaron and his sons, together with their priestly clothes, were dedicated to the LORD.
8.31: Moses said to Aaron and his sons: The LORD told me that you must boil this meat at the entrance to the sacred tent and eat it there with the bread.
8.33: and stay near the entrance to the sacred tent until the ordination ceremony ends seven days from now.
8.34: We have obeyed the LORD in everything that has been done today, so that your sins may be forgiven.
8.35: The LORD has told me that you must stay near the entrance to the tent for seven days and nights, or else you will die.
8.36: Aaron and his sons obeyed everything that the LORD had told Moses they must do.

9.1: Eight days later Moses called together Aaron, his sons, and Israel's leaders.
9.2: Then he said to Aaron: Find a young bull and a ram that have nothing wrong with them. Offer the bull to the LORD as a sacrifice for sin and the ram as a sacrifice to please him.
9.3: Tell the people of Israel that they must offer sacrifices as well. They must offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin, and a bull and a ram as a sacrifice to please the LORD. The bull and the ram must be a year old and have nothing wrong with them.
9.4: Then the people must offer a bull and a ram as a sacrifice to ask the LORD's blessing and also a grain sacrifice mixed with oil. Do this, because the LORD will appear to you today.
9.5: After the animals and the grain had been brought to the front of the sacred tent, and the people were standing there in the presence of the LORD,
9.6: Moses said: The LORD has ordered you to do this, so that he may appear to you in all of his glory.
9.7: Aaron, step up to the altar and offer the sacrifice to please the LORD, then offer the sacrifices for the forgiveness of your sins and for the sins of the people, just as the LORD has commanded.
9.8: Aaron stepped up to the altar and killed the bull that was to be the sacrifice for his sins.
9.9: His sons brought him the blood. He dipped a finger in it, smeared some on the four corners of the bronze altar, and poured out the rest at its foot.
9.10: But he sent up in smoke the fat, the kidneys, and the lower part of the liver, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
9.11: Then Aaron burned the skin and the flesh outside the camp.
9.12: After Aaron had killed the ram that was sacrificed to please the LORD, Aaron's sons brought him the blood, and he splattered it against all four sides of the altar.
9.13: They brought him each piece of the animal, including the head, and he burned them all on the altar.
9.14: He washed the insides and the hind legs and also sent them up in smoke.
9.15: Next, Aaron sacrificed the goat for the sins of the people, as he had done with the sacrifice for his own sins.
9.16: And so, he burned this sacrifice on the altar in the proper way.
9.17: He also presented the grain sacrifice and burned a handful of the flour on the altar as part of the morning sacrifice.
9.18: Finally, he killed the bull and the ram as a sacrifice to ask the LORD's blessing on the people. Aaron's sons brought him the blood, and he splattered it against the four sides of the altar.
9.19: His sons placed all the fat, as well as the kidneys and the lower part of the liver
9.20: on top of the choice ribs.
9.21: Then Aaron burned the fat on the altar and lifted up the ribs and the right hind leg to show that these were dedicated to the LORD. This was done just as the LORD had instructed Moses.
9.22: Aaron held out his hand and gave the people his blessing, before coming down from the bronze altar where he had offered the sacrifices.
9.23: He and Moses went into the sacred tent, and when they came out, they gave the people their blessing. Then the LORD appeared to the people in all of his glory.
9.24: The LORD sent fiery flames that burned up everything on the altar, and when everyone saw this, they shouted and fell to their knees to worship the LORD.

10.1: Nadab and Abihu were two of Aaron's sons, but they disobeyed the LORD by burning incense to him on a fire pan, when they were not supposed to.
10.2: Suddenly the LORD sent fiery flames and burned them to death.
10.3: Then Moses told Aaron that this was exactly what the LORD had meant when he said: "I demand respect from my priests, and I will be praised by everyone!" Aaron was speechless.
10.4: Moses sent for Mishael and Elzaphan, the two sons of Aaron's uncle Uzziel. Then he told them, "Take these two dead relatives of yours outside the camp far from the entrance to the sacred tent."
10.5: So they dragged the dead men away by their clothes.
10.6: Then Moses told Aaron and his other two sons, Eleazar and Ithamar: Don't show your sorrow by messing up your hair and tearing your priestly clothes, or the LORD will get angry. He will kill the three of you and punish everyone else. It's all right for your relatives, the people of Israel, to mourn for those he destroyed by fire.
10.7: But you are the LORD's chosen priests, and you must not leave the sacred tent, or you will die. Aaron and his two sons obeyed Moses.
10.9: When you or your sons enter the sacred tent, you must never drink beer or wine. If you do, you will die right there! This law will never change.
10.10: You must learn the difference between what is holy and what isn't holy and between the clean and the unclean.
10.11: You must also teach the people of Israel everything that I commanded Moses to say to them.
10.12: Moses told Aaron and his two sons, Eleazar and Ithamar: The grain sacrifice that was offered to give thanks to the LORD is very holy. So make bread without yeast from the part that wasn't sent up in smoke and eat it beside the altar.
10.13: The LORD has said that this belongs to you and your sons, and that it must be eaten in a holy place.
10.16: When Moses asked around and learned that the ram for the sin sacrifice had already been burned on the altar, he became angry with Eleazar and Ithamar and said,
10.17: "Why didn't you eat the meat from this sacrifice in an acceptable place? It is very holy, and the LORD has given you this sacrifice to remove Israel's sin and guilt.
10.18: Whenever an animal's blood isn't brought into the sacred tent, I commanded you to eat its meat in an acceptable place, but you burned it instead."
10.19: Their father Aaron replied, "Today two of my sons offered the sacrifice for sin and the sacrifice to please the LORD, and look what has happened to me! Would the LORD have approved if I had eaten the sacrifice for sin?"
10.20: Moses was satisfied with Aaron's reply.

11.1: The LORD told Moses and Aaron
11.2: to say to the community of Israel: You may eat
11.3: any animal that has divided hoofs and chews the cud.
11.31: Anyone who touches their dead bodies or anything touched by their dead bodies becomes unclean until evening.
11.32: If something made of wood, cloth, or leather touches one of their dead bodies, it must be washed, but it is still unclean until evening.
11.33: If any of these animals is found dead in a clay pot, the pot must be broken to pieces, and everything in it becomes unclean.
11.34: If you pour water from this pot on any food, that food becomes unclean, and anything drinkable in the pot becomes unclean.
11.35: If the dead body of one of these animals touches anything else, including ovens and stoves, that thing becomes unclean and must be destroyed.
11.36: A spring or a cistern where one of these dead animals is found is still clean, but anyone who touches the animal becomes unclean.
11.37: If the dead body of one of these animals is found lying on seeds that have been set aside for planting, the seeds remain clean.
11.38: But seeds that are soaking in water become unclean, if the dead animal is found in the water.
11.39: If an animal that may be eaten happens to die, and you touch it, you become unclean until evening.
11.40: If you eat any of its meat or carry its body away, you must wash your clothes, but you are still unclean until evening.
11.43: If you eat any of them, you will become just as disgusting and unclean as they are.
11.44: I am the LORD your God, and you must dedicate yourselves to me and be holy, just as I am holy. Don't become disgusting by eating any of these unclean creatures.
11.45: I brought you out of Egypt so that I could be your God. Now you must become holy, because I am holy!

12.2: to say to the community of Israel: If a woman gives birth to a son, she is unclean for seven days, just as she is during her monthly period.
12.3: Her son must be circumcised on the eighth day,
12.4: but her loss of blood keeps her from being completely clean for another 33 days. During this time she must not touch anything holy or go to the place of worship.
12.5: Any woman who gives birth to a daughter is unclean for two weeks, just as she is during her period. And she won't be completely clean for another 66 days.
12.6: When the mother has completed her time of cleansing, she must come to the front of the sacred tent and bring to the priest a year-old lamb as a sacrifice to please me and a dove or a pigeon as a sacrifice for sin.
12.7: After the priest offers the sacrifices to me, the mother will become completely clean from her loss of blood, whether her child is a boy or a girl.
12.8: If she cannot afford a lamb, she can offer two doves or two pigeons, one as a sacrifice to please me and the other as a sacrifice for sin.

13.1: The LORD told Moses and Aaron to say to the people:

16.25: The fat from these sacrifices for sin must be sent up in smoke on the bronze altar.

27.1: Zelophehad was from the Manasseh tribe, and he had five daughters, whose names were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
27.2: One day his daughters went to the sacred tent, where they met with Moses, Eleazar, and some other leaders of Israel, as well as a large crowd of Israelites. The young women said:
27.3: You know that our father died in the desert. But it was for something he did wrong, not for joining with Korah in rebelling against the LORD. Our father left no sons
27.4: to carry on his family name. But why should his name die out for that reason? Give us some land like the rest of his relatives in our clan, so our father's name can live on.
27.5: Moses asked the LORD what should be done,
27.7: Zelophehad's daughters are right. They should each be given part of the land their father would have received.
27.8: Tell the Israelites that when a man dies without a son, his daughter will inherit his land.
27.9: If he has no daughter, his brothers will inherit the land.
27.10: But if he has no brothers, his father's brothers will inherit the land.
27.11: And if his father has no brothers, the land must be given to his nearest relative in the clan. This is my law, and the Israelites must obey it.
27.12: The LORD said to Moses, "One day you will go up into the Abarim Mountains, and from there you will see the land I am giving the Israelites.
27.13: After you have seen it, you will die, just like your brother Aaron,
27.14: because both of you disobeyed me at Meribah near the town of Kadesh in the Zin Desert. When the Israelites insulted me there, you didn't believe in my holy power."
27.16: "You are the LORD God, and you know what is in everyone's heart. So I ask you to appoint a leader for Israel.
27.17: Your people need someone to lead them into battle, or else they will be like sheep wandering around without a shepherd."
27.18: The LORD answered, "Joshua son of Nun can do the job. Place your hands on him to show that he is the one to take your place.
27.19: Then go with him and tell him to stand in front of Eleazar the priest and the Israelites. Appoint Joshua as their new leader
27.20: and tell them they must now obey him, just as they obey you.
27.21: But Joshua must depend on Eleazar to find out from me what I want him to do as he leads Israel into battle."
27.22: Moses followed the LORD's instructions and took Joshua to Eleazar and the people,
27.23: then he placed his hands on Joshua and appointed him Israel's leader.

28.2: to say to the people of Israel: Offer sacrifices to me at the appointed times of worship, so that I will smell the smoke and be pleased.

28.5: Along with each of them, one kilogram of your finest flour mixed with a liter of olive oil must be offered as a grain sacrifice.

28.7: Finally, along with each of these two sacrifices, a liter of wine must be poured on the altar as a drink offering.

28.11: On the first day of each month, bring to the altar two bulls, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. Then offer these as sacrifices to please me.

28.16: Celebrate Passover in honor of me on the fourteenth day of the first month of each year.

28.20: Three kilograms of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with each bull as a grain sacrifice. Two kilograms of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,

28.25: Then on the last day of the festival, you must once again rest from work and come together for worship.

28.27: Offer two young bulls, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old as sacrifices to please me.
28.28: Three kilograms of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with each bull as a grain sacrifice. Two kilograms of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,

29.1: On the first day of the seventh month, you must rest from your work and come together to celebrate at the sound of the trumpets.
29.2: Bring to the altar one bull, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. And then offer these as sacrifices to please me.
29.3: Three kilograms of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with the bull as a grain sacrifice. Two kilograms of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,
29.4: and one kilogram of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.

29.6: These sacrifices will be made in addition to the regular daily sacrifices and the sacrifices for the first day of the month. The smoke from these sacrifices will please me.

29.10: and one kilogram of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.

29.13: On the first day, you must rest from your work and come together for worship. Bring to the altar 13 bulls, 2 full-grown rams, and 14 rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. Then offer these as sacrifices to please me.
29.14: Three kilograms of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with each bull as a grain sacrifice. Two kilograms of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the rams,
29.15: and one kilogram of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.
29.16: You must also offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin. These are to be offered in addition to the regular daily sacrifices.
29.35: On the eighth day, you must once again rest from your work and come together for worship.
29.36: Bring to the altar one bull, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. Then offer these as sacrifices to please me.
29.37: You must also offer the proper grain sacrifices and drink offerings of wine with each animal.
29.38: And offer a goat as the sacrifice to ask forgiveness for the people. These sacrifices are made in addition to the regular daily sacrifices.
29.39: You must offer all these sacrifices to me at the appointed times of worship, together with any offerings that are voluntarily given or given because of a promise.
29.40: Moses told the people of Israel everything the LORD had told him about the sacrifices.

30.1: The LORD told Moses to say to Israel's tribal leaders:
30.2: When one of you men makes a promise to the LORD, you must keep your word.
30.3: Suppose a young woman who is still living with her parents makes a promise to the LORD.
30.4: If her father hears about it and says nothing, she must keep her promise.
30.5: But if he hears about it and objects, then she no longer has to keep her promise. The LORD will forgive her, because her father did not agree with the promise.
30.8: But if her husband hears about the promise and objects, she no longer has to keep it, and the LORD will forgive her.
30.9: Widows and divorced women must keep every promise they make to the LORD.
30.10: Suppose a married woman makes a promise to the LORD.
30.11: If her husband hears about the promise and says nothing, she must do what she said.
30.12: But if he hears about the promise and does object, she no longer has to keep it. The LORD will forgive her, because her husband would not allow her to keep the promise.
30.13: Her husband has the final say about any promises she makes to the LORD.
30.14: If her husband hears about a promise and says nothing about it for a whole day, she must do what she said--since he did not object, the promise must be kept.
30.15: But if he waits until the next day to stop her from keeping her promise, he is the one who must be punished.
30.16: These are the laws that the LORD gave Moses about husbands and wives, and about young daughters who still live at home.

31.15: and said, "I can't believe you let the women live!

31.20: Then wash your clothes and anything made from animal skin, goat's hair, or wood."
31.24: Wash your clothes on the seventh day, and after that, you will be clean and may return to the camp."
31.30: From the half that belongs to the people, set aside one out of every 50 and give these to the Levites in charge of the sacred tent.

31.48: The army commanders went to Moses

32.2: So they went to Moses, Eleazar, and the other leaders of Israel and said,
32.5: would you let us stay here east of the Jordan River and have this land as our own?"
32.6: Moses answered: You mean you'd stay here while the rest of the Israelites go into battle?
32.7: If you did that, it would discourage the others from crossing over into the land the LORD promised them.
32.8: This is exactly what happened when I sent your ancestors from Kadesh-Barnea to explore the land.

32.11: And he said that no one who was 20 years or older when they left Egypt would enter the land he had promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Not one of those people believed in the LORD's power,

32.13: but he was so angry with the others that he forced them to wander around in the desert for 40 years. By that time everyone who had sinned against him had died.

32.15: If you reject the LORD, he will once again abandon his people and leave them here in the desert. And you will be to blame!
32.16: The men from Reuben and Gad replied: Let us build places to keep our sheep and goats, and towns for our wives and children,
32.17: where they can stay and be safe. Then we'll prepare to fight and lead the other tribes into battle.

32.20: Moses said: You promised that you would be ready to fight for the LORD.
32.21: You also agreed to cross the Jordan and stay with the rest of the Israelites, until the LORD forces our enemies out of the land. If you do these things,
32.22: then after the LORD helps Israel capture the land, you can return to your own land. You will no longer have to stay with the others.
32.23: But if you don't keep your promise, you will sin against the LORD and be punished.
32.24: Go ahead and build towns for your wives and children, and places for your sheep and goats. Just be sure to do what you have promised.
32.25: The men from Reuben and Gad answered: Sir, we will do just what you have said.
32.26: Our wives and children and sheep and cattle will stay here in the towns in Gilead.
32.27: But those of us who are prepared for battle will cross the Jordan and fight for the LORD.
32.28: Then Moses said to Eleazar, Joshua, and the family leaders,
32.29: "Make sure that the tribes of Gad and Reuben prepare for battle and cross the Jordan River with you. If they do, then after the land is in your control, give them the region of Gilead as their tribal land.

32.31: The tribes of Gad and Reuben replied, "We are your servants and will do whatever the LORD has commanded.
32.32: We will cross the Jordan River, ready to fight for the LORD in Canaan. But the land we will inherit as our own will be on this side of the river."
32.33: So Moses gave the tribes of Gad, Reuben, and half of Manasseh the territory and towns that King Sihon the Amorite had ruled, as well as the territory and towns that King Og of Bashan had ruled.

32.37: The tribe of Reuben rebuilt Heshbon, Elealeh, Kiriathaim,
32.38: Sibmah, as well as the towns that used to be known as Nebo and Baal-Meon. They renamed all those places.
32.39: The clan of Machir from the tribe of East Manasseh went to the region of Gilead, captured its towns, and forced out the Amorites.
32.40: So Moses gave the Machirites the region of Gilead, and they settled there.
32.41: Jair from the Manasseh tribe captured villages and renamed them "Villages of Jair."
32.42: Nobah captured the town of Kenath with its villages and renamed it Nobah.

36.1: One day the family leaders from the Gilead clan of the Manasseh tribe went to Moses and the other family leaders of Israel

1.6: People of Israel, when we were in our camp at Mount Sinai, the LORD our God told us: You have stayed here long enough.
1.7: Leave this place and go into the land that belongs to the Amorites and their neighbors the Canaanites. This land includes the Jordan River valley, the hill country, the western foothills, the Southern Desert, the Mediterranean seacoast, the Lebanon Mountains, and all the territory as far as the Euphrates River.
1.8: I give you this land, just as I promised your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Now you must go and take the land.
1.9: Right after the LORD commanded us to leave Mount Sinai, I told you: Israel, being your leader is too big a job for one person.
1.10: The LORD our God has blessed us, and so now there are as many of us as there are stars in the sky.
1.11: God has even promised to bless us a thousand times more, and I pray that he will.
1.12: But I cannot take care of all your problems and settle all your arguments alone.
1.13: Each tribe must choose some experienced men who are known for their wisdom and understanding, and I will make those men the official leaders of their tribes.
1.15: Then I took these men, who were already wise and respected leaders, and I appointed them as your official leaders. Some of them became military officers in charge of groups of 1,000, or 100, or 50, or 10,
1.16: and others became judges. I gave these judges the following instructions: When you settle legal cases, your decisions must be fair. It doesn't matter if the case is between two Israelites, or between an Israelite and a foreigner living in your community.
1.17: And it doesn't matter if one is helpless and the other is powerful. Don't be afraid of anyone! No matter who shows up in your court, God will help you make a fair decision. If any case is too hard for you, bring the people to me, and I will make the decision.
1.18: After I gave these instructions to the judges, I taught you the LORD's commands.
1.19: The LORD had commanded us to leave Mount Sinai and go to the hill country that belonged to the Amorites, so we started out into the huge desert. You remember how frightening it was, but soon we were at Kadesh-Barnea,
1.22: Then all of you came to me and said, "Before we go into the land, let's send some men to explore it. When they come back, they can tell us about the towns we will find and what roads we should take to get there."
1.23: It seemed like a good idea, so I chose twelve men, one from each tribe.
1.24: They explored the hill country as far as Bunch Valley
1.25: and even brought back some of the fruit. They said, "The LORD our God is giving us good land."
1.26: You did not want to go into the land, and you refused to obey the LORD your God.
1.27: You stayed in your tents and grumbled, "The LORD must hate us--he brought us out of Egypt, just so he could hand us over to the Amorites and get rid of us.
1.28: We are afraid, because the men who explored the land told us that the cities are large, with walls that reach to the sky. The people who live there are taller and stronger than we are, and some of them are Anakim. We have nowhere to go."
1.30: The LORD our God will lead the way. He will fight on our side, just as he did when we saw him do all those things to the Egyptians.
1.31: And you know that the LORD has taken care of us the whole time we've been in the desert, just as you might carry one of your children."
1.32: But you still would not trust the LORD,
1.33: even though he had always been with us in the desert. During the daytime, the LORD was in the cloud, leading us in the right direction and showing us where to camp. And at night, he was there in the fire.
1.34: You had made the LORD angry, and he said:
1.35: You people of this generation are evil, and I refuse to let you go into the good land that I promised your ancestors.
1.36: Caleb son of Jephunneh is the only one of your generation that I will allow to go in. He obeyed me completely, so I will give him and his descendants the land he explored.
1.37: The LORD was even angry with me because of you people, and he said, "Moses, I won't let you go into the land either.
1.38: Instead, I will let Joshua your assistant lead Israel to conquer the land. So encourage him."
1.39: Then the LORD spoke to you again: People of Israel, you said that your innocent young children would be taken prisoner in the battle for the land. But someday I will let them go into the land, and with my help they will conquer it and live there.
1.40: Now, turn around and go back into the desert by way of Red Sea Road.
1.41: Then you told me, "We disobeyed the LORD our God, but now we want to obey him. We will go into the hill country and fight, just as he told us to do." So you picked up your weapons, thinking it would be easy to take over the hill country.
1.42: But the LORD said, "Moses, warn them not to go into the hill country. I won't help them fight, and their enemies will defeat them."
1.43: I told you what the LORD had said, but you paid no attention. You disobeyed him and went into the hill country anyway. You thought you were so great!
1.44: But when the Amorites in the hill country attacked from their towns, you ran from them as you would run from a swarm of bees. The Amorites chased your troops into Seir as far as Hormah, killing them as they went.
1.45: Then you came back to the place of worship at Kadesh-Barnea and wept, but the LORD would not listen to your prayers.
1.46: After we had been in Kadesh for a few months, we obeyed the LORD and headed back into the desert by way of Red Sea Road.

5.1: Moses called together the people of Israel and said: Today I am telling you the laws and teachings that you must follow, so listen carefully.
5.2: The LORD our God made an agreement with our nation at Mount Sinai.
5.3: That agreement wasn't only with our ancestors but with us, who are here today.
5.4: The LORD himself spoke to you out of the fire,
5.5: but you were afraid of the fire and refused to go up the mountain. So I spoke with the LORD for you, then I told you that he had said:
5.6: I am the LORD your God, the one who brought you out of Egypt where you were slaves.
5.7: Do not worship any god except me.
5.8: Do not make idols that look like anything in the sky or on earth or in the ocean under the earth.
5.9: Don't bow down and worship idols. I am the LORD your God, and I demand all your love. If you reject me and worship idols, I will punish your families for three or four generations.
5.10: But if you love me and obey my laws, I will be kind to your families for thousands of generations.
5.11: Do not misuse my name. I am the LORD your God, and I will punish anyone who misuses my name.
5.12: Show respect for the Sabbath Day--it belongs to me.
5.13: You have six days when you can do your work,
5.14: but the seventh day of the week belongs to me, your God. No one is to work on that day--not you, your children, your oxen or donkeys or any other animal, not even those foreigners who live in your towns. And don't make your slaves do any work.
5.15: This special day of rest will remind you that I reached out my mighty arm and rescued you from slavery in Egypt.
5.16: Respect your father and mother, and you will live a long and successful life in the land I am giving you.
5.20: Do not tell lies about others.
5.21: Do not desire to possess anything that belongs to another person--not a house, a wife, a husband, a slave, an ox, a donkey, or anything else.
5.22: When we were gathered at the mountain, the LORD spoke to us in a loud voice from the dark fiery cloud. The LORD gave us these commands, and only these. Then he wrote them on two flat stones and gave them to me.
5.23: When fire blazed from the mountain, and you heard the voice coming from the darkness, your tribal leaders came to me
5.24: and said: Today the LORD our God has shown us how powerful and glorious he is. He spoke to us from the fire, and we learned that people can live, even though God speaks to them.
5.25: But we don't want to take a chance on being killed by that terrible fire, and if we keep on hearing the LORD's voice, we will die.
5.26: Has anyone else ever heard the only true God speaking from fire, as we have? And even if they have, would they live to tell about it?
5.27: Moses, go up close and listen to the LORD. Then come back and tell us, and we will do everything he says.
5.28: The LORD heard you and said: Moses, I heard what the people said to you, and I approve.
5.29: I wish they would always worship me with fear and trembling and be this willing to obey me! Then they and their children would always enjoy a successful life.
5.30: Now, tell them to return to their tents,
5.31: but you come back here to me. After I tell you my laws and teachings, you will repeat them to the people, so they can obey these laws in the land I am giving them.
5.32: Israel, you must carefully obey the LORD's commands.
5.33: Follow them, because they make a path that will lead to a long successful life in the land the LORD your God is giving you.

6.4: Listen, Israel! The LORD our God is the only true God!
6.5: So love the LORD your God with all your heart, soul, and strength.
6.7: and tell them to your children over and over again. Talk about them all the time, whether you're at home or walking along the road or going to bed at night, or getting up in the morning.

7.1: People of Israel, the LORD your God will help you take the land of the Hittites, the Girgashites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites. These seven nations have more people and are stronger than Israel, but when you attack them,
7.2: the LORD will force them out of the land. Then you must destroy them without mercy. Don't make any peace treaties with them,
7.3: and don't let your sons and daughters marry any of them.
7.4: If you do, those people will lead your descendants to worship other gods and to turn their backs on the LORD. That will make him very angry, and he will quickly destroy Israel.
7.5: So when you conquer these nations, tear down the altars where they worship their gods. Break up their sacred stones, cut down the poles that they use in worshiping the goddess Asherah, and throw their idols in the fire.
7.6: Israel, you are the chosen people of the LORD your God. There are many nations on this earth, but he chose only Israel to be his very own.
7.7: You were the weakest of all nations,
7.8: but the LORD chose you because he loves you and because he had made a promise to your ancestors. Then with his mighty arm, he rescued you from the king of Egypt, who had made you his slaves.
7.9: You know that the LORD your God is the only true God. So love him and obey his commands, and he will faithfully keep his agreement with you and your descendants for a thousand generations.
7.10: But if you turn against the LORD, he will quickly destroy you.
7.11: So be sure to obey his laws and teachings I am giving you today.
7.12: If you completely obey these laws, the LORD your God will be loyal and keep the agreement he made with you, just as he promised our ancestors.
7.13: The LORD will love you and bless you by giving you many children and plenty of food, wine, and olive oil. Your herds of cattle will have many calves, and your flocks of sheep will have many lambs.
7.14: God will bless you more than any other nation--your families will grow and your livestock increase.
7.15: You will no longer suffer with the same horrible diseases that you sometimes had in Egypt. You will be healthy, but the LORD will make your enemies suffer from those diseases.
7.16: When the LORD helps you defeat your enemies, you must destroy them without pity! And don't get trapped into worshiping their gods.
7.17: You may be thinking, "How can we destroy these nations? They are more powerful than we are."
7.18: But stop worrying! Just remember what the LORD your God did to Egypt and its king.
7.19: You saw how the LORD used his tremendous power to work great miracles and bring you out of Egypt. And he will again work miracles for you when you face these enemies you fear so much.
7.20: Some of them may try to survive by hiding from you, but the LORD will make them panic, and soon they will be dead.
7.21: So don't be frightened when you meet them in battle. The LORD your God is great and fearsome, and he will fight at your side.
7.22: As you attack these nations, the LORD will force them out little by little. He won't let you get rid of them all at once--if he did, there wouldn't be enough people living in the land to keep down the number of wild animals.
7.25: After you conquer a nation, burn their idols. Don't get trapped into wanting the silver or gold on an idol. Even the metal on an idol is disgusting to the LORD,
7.26: so destroy it. If you bring it home with you, both you and your house will be destroyed. Stay away from those disgusting idols!

8.1: Israel, do you want to go into the land the LORD promised your ancestors? Do you want to capture it, live there, and become a powerful nation? Then be sure to obey every command I am giving you.
8.2: Don't forget how the LORD your God has led you through the desert for the past 40 years. He wanted to find out if you were truly willing to obey him and depend on him,
8.3: so he made you go hungry. Then he gave you manna, a kind of food that you and your ancestors had never even heard about. The LORD was teaching you that people need more than food to live--they need every word that the LORD has spoken.
8.4: Over the past 40 years, your clothing hasn't worn out, and your feet haven't swollen.
8.5: So keep in mind that the LORD has been correcting you, just as parents correct their children.
8.6: Obey the commands the LORD your God has given you and worship him with fear and trembling.
8.7: The LORD your God is bringing you into a good land with streams that flow from springs in the valleys and hills.
8.10: After you eat and are full, give praise to the LORD your God for the good land he gave you.
8.11: Make sure that you never forget the LORD or disobey his laws and teachings that I am giving you today. If you always obey them,
8.12: you will have plenty to eat, and you will build good houses to live in.
8.13: You will get more and more cattle, sheep, silver, gold, and other possessions.
8.14: But when all this happens, don't be proud! Don't forget that you were once slaves in Egypt and that it was the LORD who set you free.
8.15: Remember how he led you in that huge and frightening desert where poisonous snakes and scorpions live. There was no water, but the LORD split open a rock, and water poured out so you could drink.
8.16: He also gave you manna, a kind of food your ancestors had never even heard about. The LORD was testing you to make you trust him, so that later on he could be good to you.
8.17: When you become successful, don't say, "I'm rich, and I've earned it all myself."
8.18: Instead, remember that the LORD your God gives you the strength to make a living. That's how he keeps the promise he made to your ancestors.

9.7: Don't ever forget how you kept rebelling and making the LORD angry the whole time you were in the desert. You rebelled from the day you left Egypt until the day you arrived here.

10.4: where the LORD wrote the Ten Commandments on them, just as he had done the first time. The commandments were exactly what he had announced from the fire, when you were gathered at the mountain. After the LORD returned the stones to me,

10.11: Instead, he told me, "Moses, get ready to lead the people into the land that I promised their ancestors."
10.12: People of Israel, what does the LORD your God want from you? The LORD wants you to respect and follow him, to love and serve him with all your heart and soul,
10.13: and to obey his laws and teachings that I am giving you today. Do this, and all will go well for you.
10.14: Everything belongs to the LORD your God, not only the earth and everything on it, but also the sky and the highest heavens.
10.15: Yet the LORD loved your ancestors and wanted them to belong to him. So he chose them and their descendants rather than any other nation, and today you are still his people.
10.16: Remember your agreement with the LORD and stop being so stubborn.
10.17: The LORD your God is more powerful than all other gods and lords, and his tremendous power is to be feared. His decisions are always fair, and you cannot bribe him to change his mind.
10.18: The LORD defends the rights of orphans and widows. He cares for foreigners and gives them food and clothing.
10.19: And you should also care for them, because you were foreigners in Egypt.
10.20: Respect the LORD your God, be faithful, and serve only him, making promises in his name.
10.21: Offer your praises to him, because you have seen him work such terrifying miracles for you.
10.22: When your ancestors went to live in Egypt, there were only 70 of them. But the LORD has blessed you, and now there are more of you than there are stars in the sky.

11.6: And you saw how the LORD made the ground open up in the middle of our camp underneath the tents of Dathan and Abiram, who were swallowed up along with their families, their animals, and their tents.
11.7: With your own eyes, you saw the LORD's mighty power do all these things.

11.10: It's better land than you had in Egypt, where you had to struggle just to water your crops.
11.11: But the hills and valleys in the promised land are watered by rain from heaven,
11.12: because the LORD your God keeps his eye on this land and takes care of it all year long.
11.13: The LORD your God commands you to love him and to serve him with all your heart and soul. If you obey him,
11.16: But watch out! You will be tempted to turn your backs on the LORD. And if you worship other gods,
11.17: the LORD will become angry and keep the rain from falling. Nothing will grow in your fields, and you will die and disappear from the good land that the LORD is giving you.
11.18: Memorize these laws and think about them. Write down copies and tie them to your wrists and your foreheads to help you obey them.
11.19: Teach them to your children. Talk about them all the time--whether you're at home or walking along the road or going to bed at night, or getting up in the morning.
11.20: Write them on the door frames of your homes and on your town gates.
11.21: Then you and your descendants will live a long time in the land that the LORD promised your ancestors. Your families will live there as long as the sky is above the earth.
11.22: Love the LORD your God faithfully and obey all the laws and teachings I'm giving you today. If you live the way the LORD wants,
11.23: he will help you take the land. And even though the nations there are more powerful than you, the LORD will force them to leave when you attack.
11.24: You will capture the land everywhere you go, from the Southern Desert to the Lebanon Mountains, and from the Euphrates River west to the Mediterranean Sea.
11.25: No one will be able to stand up to you. The LORD will make everyone terrified of you, just as he promised.
11.26: You have a choice--do you want the LORD to bless you, or do you want him to put a curse on you?
11.27: Today I am giving you his laws, and if you obey him, he will bless you.
11.28: But if you disobey him and worship those gods that have never done anything for you, the LORD will put a curse on you.
11.29: After the LORD your God helps you take the land, you must have a ceremony where you announce his blessings from Mount Gerizim and his curses from Mount Ebal.
11.30: You know that these two mountains are west of the Jordan River in land now controlled by the Canaanites living in the Jordan River valley. The mountains are west of the road near the sacred trees of Moreh on the other side of Gilgal.
11.31: Soon you will cross the Jordan River to conquer the land that the LORD your God is giving you. And when you have settled there,
11.32: be careful to obey his laws and teachings that I am giving you today.

12.1: Now I'll tell you the laws and teachings that you have to obey as long as you live. Your ancestors worshiped the LORD, and he is giving you this land.
12.2: But the nations that live there worship other gods. So after you capture the land, you must completely destroy their places of worship--on mountains and hills or in the shade of large trees.
12.3: Wherever these nations worship their gods, you must tear down their altars, break their sacred stones, burn the sacred poles used in worshiping the goddess Asherah, and smash their idols to pieces. Destroy these places of worship so completely that no one will remember they were ever there.
12.4: Don't worship the LORD your God in the way those nations worship their gods.
12.22: It is the same as eating the meat from a deer or a gazelle that you kill when you go hunting. And in this way, anyone who is unclean and unfit for worship can have some of the meat.
12.25: Do you want the LORD to make you successful? Do you want your children to be successful even after you are gone? Then do what pleases the LORD and don't eat blood.
12.28: If you obey these laws, you will be doing what the LORD your God says is right and good. Then he will help you and your descendants be successful.
12.29: Israel, as you go into the land and attack the nations that are there, the LORD will get rid of them, and you can have their land.
12.30: But that's when you must be especially careful not to ask, "How did those nations worship their gods? Shouldn't we worship the LORD in the same way?"
12.31: No, you should not! The LORD hates the disgusting way those nations worship their gods, because they even burn their sons and daughters as sacrifices.
12.32: Obey all the laws and teachings I am giving you. Don't add any, and don't take any away.

13.3: If the prophet says this, don't listen! The LORD your God will be watching to find out whether or not you love him with all your heart and soul.
13.4: You must be completely faithful to the LORD. Worship and obey only the LORD and do this with fear and trembling,
13.5: because he rescued you from slavery in Egypt. If a prophet tells you to disobey the LORD your God and to stop worshiping him, then that prophet is evil and must be put to death.
13.11: And when the rest of Israel hears about it, they will be afraid, and no one else will ever do such an evil thing again.
13.12: After the LORD your God gives you towns to live in, you may hear a rumor about one of the towns.
13.13: You may hear that some worthless people have talked everyone there into worshiping other gods, even though these gods had never done anything for them.
13.14: You must carefully find out if the rumor is true. Then if the people of that town have actually done such a disgusting thing in your own country,
13.15: you must take your swords and kill every one of them, and their livestock too.
13.18: That's why you must do what the LORD your God says is right. I am giving you his laws and teachings today, and you must obey them.

14.1: People of Israel, you are the LORD's children, so when you mourn for the dead, you must not cut yourselves or shave your forehead.
14.2: Out of all the nations on this earth, the LORD your God chose you to be his own. You belong to the LORD, so don't behave like those who worship other gods.
14.6: It is all right to eat meat from any animals that have divided hoofs and also chew the cud.
14.7: But don't eat camels, rabbits, and rock badgers. These animals chew the cud but do not have divided hoofs. You must treat them as unclean.
14.8: And don't eat pork, since pigs have divided hoofs, but they do not chew their cud. Don't even touch a dead pig!
14.9: You can eat any fish that has fins and scales. But there are other creatures that live in the water,
14.10: and if they do not have fins and scales, you must not eat them. Treat them as unclean.
14.11: You can eat any clean bird.
14.19: Swarming insects are unclean, so don't eat them.
14.20: However, you are allowed to eat certain kinds of winged insects.
14.21: You belong to the LORD your God, so if you happen to find a dead animal, don't eat its meat. You may give it to foreigners who live in your town or sell it to foreigners who are visiting your town. Don't boil a young goat in its mother's milk.
14.22: People of Israel, every year you must set aside ten percent of your grain harvest.
14.23: Also set aside ten percent of your wine and olive oil, and the first-born of every cow, sheep, and goat. Take these to the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped, and eat them there. This will teach you to always respect the LORD your God.
14.24: But suppose you can't carry that ten percent of your harvest to the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped. If you live too far away, or if the LORD gives you a big harvest,
14.25: then sell this part and take the money there instead.
14.26: When you and your family arrive, spend the money on food for a big celebration. Buy cattle, sheep, goats, wine, beer, and if there are any other kinds of food that you want, buy those too.
14.27: And since people of the Levi tribe won't own any land for growing crops, remember to ask the Levites to celebrate with you.
14.28: Every third year, instead of using the ten percent of your harvest for a big celebration, bring it into town and put it in a community storehouse.
14.29: The Levites have no land of their own, so you must give them food from the storehouse. You must also give food to the poor who live in your town, including orphans, widows, and foreigners. If they have enough to eat, then the LORD your God will be pleased and make you successful in everything you do.

15.3: This law applies only to loans you have made to other Israelites. Foreigners will still have to pay back what you have loaned them.
15.7: After the LORD your God gives land to each of you, there may be poor Israelites in the town where you live. If there are, then don't be mean and selfish with your money.
15.8: Instead, be kind and lend them what they need.
15.9: Be careful! Don't say to yourself, "Soon it will be the seventh year, and then I won't be able to get my money back." It would be horrible for you to think that way and to be so selfish that you refuse to help the poor. They are your relatives, and if you don't help them, they may ask the LORD to decide whether you have done wrong. And he will say that you are guilty.
15.10: You should be happy to give the poor what they need, because then the LORD will make you successful in everything you do.
15.11: There will always be some Israelites who are poor and needy. That's why I am commanding you to be generous with them.
15.12: If any of you buy Israelites as slaves, you must set them free after six years.
15.13: And don't just tell them they are free to leave--
15.14: give them sheep and goats and a good supply of grain and wine. The more the LORD has given you, the more you should give them.
15.15: I am commanding you to obey the LORD as a reminder that you were slaves in Egypt before he set you free.
15.16: But one of your slaves may say, "I love you and your family, and I would be better off staying with you, so please don't make me leave."
15.17: Take the slave to the door of your house and push a sharp metal rod through one earlobe and into the door. Such slaves will belong to you for life, whether they are men or women.
15.18: Don't complain when you have to set a slave free. After all, you got six years of service at half the cost of hiring someone to do the work.
15.19: If the first-born animal of a cow or sheep or goat is a male, it must be given to the LORD. Don't put first-born cattle to work or cut wool from first-born sheep.
15.20: Instead, each year you must take the first-born of these animals to the place where the LORD your God chooses to be worshiped. You and your family will sacrifice them to the LORD and then eat them as part of a sacred meal.
15.21: But if the animal is lame or blind or has something else wrong with it, you must not sacrifice it to the LORD your God.
15.22: You can butcher it where you live, and eat it just like the meat of a deer or gazelle that you kill while hunting. Even those people who are unclean and unfit for worship can have some.
15.23: But you must never eat the blood of an animal--let it drain out on the ground.

16.1: People of Israel, you must celebrate Passover in the month of Abib, because one night in that month years ago, the LORD your God rescued you from Egypt.
16.2: The Passover sacrifice must be a cow, a sheep, or a goat, and you must offer it at the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped.
16.5: Don't offer the Passover sacrifice in just any town where you happen to live.
16.6: It must be offered at the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped. Kill the sacrifice at sunset, the time of day when you left Egypt.
16.7: Then cook it and eat it there at the place of worship, returning to your tents the next morning.
16.8: Eat thin bread for the next six days. Then on the seventh day, don't do any work. Instead, come together and worship the LORD.
16.9: Seven weeks after you start your grain harvest,
16.12: Remember that you used to be slaves in Egypt, so obey these laws.
16.16: Each year there are three festivals when all Israelite men must go to the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped. These are the Festival of Thin Bread, the Harvest Festival, and the Festival of Shelters. And don't forget to take along a gift for the LORD.
16.17: The bigger the harvest the LORD gives you, the bigger your gift should be.
16.20: People of Israel, if you want to enjoy a long and successful life, make sure that everyone is treated with justice in the land the LORD is giving you.
16.21: When you build the altar for offering sacrifices to the LORD your God, don't set up a sacred pole for the worship of the goddess Asherah.
16.22: And don't set up a sacred stone! The LORD hates these things.

17.1: If an ox or a sheep has something wrong with it, don't offer it as a sacrifice to the LORD your God--he will be disgusted!
17.4: So when you hear that someone in your town is committing this disgusting sin, you must carefully find out if that person really is guilty.
17.13: When other Israelites hear about it, they will be afraid and obey the decisions of the court.
17.14: People of Israel, after you capture the land the LORD your God is giving you, and after you settle on it, you will say, "We want a king, just like the nations around us."
17.15: Go ahead and appoint a king, but make sure that he is an Israelite and that he is the one the LORD has chosen.
17.16: The king should not have many horses, especially those from Egypt. The LORD has said never to go back there again.
17.17: And the king must not have a lot of wives--they might tempt him to be unfaithful to the LORD. Finally, the king must not try to get huge amounts of silver and gold.
17.18: The official copy of God's laws will be kept by the priests of the Levi tribe. So, as soon as anyone becomes king, he must go to the priests and write out a copy of these laws while they watch.
17.19: Each day the king must read and obey these laws, so that he will learn to worship the LORD with fear and trembling
17.20: and not think that he's better than everyone else. If the king completely obeys the LORD's commands, he and his descendants will rule Israel for many years.

18.1: The people of the Levi tribe, including the priests, will not receive any land. Instead, they will receive part of the sacrifices that are offered to the LORD,
18.2: because he has promised to provide for them in this way.
18.3: When you sacrifice a bull or sheep, the priests will be given the shoulder, the jaws, and the stomach.
18.4: In addition, they will receive the first part of your grain harvest and part of your first batches of wine and olive oil. You must also give them the first wool that is cut from your sheep each year.
18.5: Give these gifts to the priests, because the LORD has chosen them and their descendants out of all the tribes of Israel to be his special servants at the place of worship.
18.6: Any Levite can leave his hometown, and go to the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped,
18.7: and then be a special servant of the LORD there, just like all the other Levites.
18.8: Some Levites may have money from selling family possessions, and others may not. But all Levites serving at the place of worship will receive the same amount of food from the sacrifices and gifts brought by the people.
18.9: Soon you will go into the land that the LORD your God is giving you. The nations that live there do things that are disgusting to the LORD, and you must not follow their example.
18.12: The LORD is disgusted with anyone who does these things, and that's why he will help you destroy the nations that are in the land.
18.13: Never be guilty of doing any of these disgusting things!
18.14: You will go in and take the land from nations that practice magic and witchcraft. But the LORD your God won't allow you to do those things.
18.15: Instead, he will choose one of your own people to be a prophet just like me, and you must do what that prophet says.
18.16: You were asking for a prophet the day you were gathered at Mount Sinai and said to the LORD, "Please don't let us hear your voice or see this terrible fire again--if we do, we will die!"
18.17: Then the LORD told me: Moses, they have said the right thing.
18.18: So when I want to speak to them, I will choose one of them to be a prophet like you. I will give my message to that prophet, who will tell the people exactly what I have said.
18.19: Since the message comes from me, anyone who doesn't obey the message will have to answer to me.
18.20: But if I haven't spoken, and a prophet claims to have a message from me, you must kill that prophet, and you must also kill any prophet who claims to have a message from another god.
18.21: You may be asking yourselves, "How can we tell if a prophet's message really comes from the LORD?"
18.22: You will know, because if the LORD says something will happen, it will happen. And if it doesn't, you will know that the prophet was falsely claiming to speak for the LORD. Don't be afraid of any prophet whose message doesn't come from the LORD.

19.1: Soon you will go into the land and attack the nations. The LORD your God will destroy them and give you their lands, towns, and homes. Then after you are settled,
19.5: For example, suppose you and a friend go into the forest to cut wood. You are chopping down a tree with an ax, when the ax head slips off the handle, hits your friend, and kills him. You can run to one of the Safe Towns and save your life.
19.6: You don't deserve to die, since you did not mean to harm your friend. But he did get killed, and his relatives might be very angry. They might even choose one of the men from their family to track you down and kill you. If it is too far to one of the Safe Towns, the victim's relative might be able to catch you and kill you.
19.7: That's why I said there must be three Safe Towns.
19.10: You will need them, so innocent people won't be killed on your land while they are trying to reach a Safe Town that is too far away. You will be guilty of murder, if innocent people lose their lives because you didn't name enough Safe Towns in the land the LORD your God will give you.
19.11: But what if you really do commit murder? Suppose one of you hates a neighbor. So you wait in a deserted place, kill the neighbor, and run to a Safe Town.
19.12: If that happens, the leaders of your town must send messengers to bring you back from the Safe Town. They will hand you over to one of the victim's relatives, who will put you to death.
19.13: Israel, for the good of the whole country, you must kill anyone who murders an innocent person. Never show mercy to a murderer!
19.14: In the land the LORD is giving you, there are already stones set up to mark the property lines between fields. So don't move those stones.
19.15: Before you are convicted of a crime, at least two witnesses must be able to testify that you did it.
19.16: If you accuse someone of a crime, but seem to be lying,

20.1: If you have to go to war, you may find yourselves facing an enemy army that is bigger than yours and that has horses and chariots. But don't be afraid! The LORD your God rescued you from Egypt, and he will help you fight.
20.2: Before you march into battle, a priest will go to the front of the army
20.3: and say, "Soldiers of Israel, listen to me! Today when you go into battle, don't be afraid of the enemy, and when you see them, don't panic.
20.4: The LORD your God will fight alongside you and help you win the battle."
20.5: Then the tribal officials will say to the troops: If any of you have built a new house, but haven't yet moved in, you may go home. It isn't right for you to die in battle and for somebody else to live in your new house.
20.6: If any of you have planted a vineyard but haven't had your first grape harvest, you may go home. It isn't right for you to die in battle and for somebody else to enjoy your grapes.
20.7: If any of you are engaged to be married, you may go back home and get married. It isn't right for you to die in battle and for somebody else to marry the woman you are engaged to.
20.8: Finally, if any of you are afraid, you may go home. We don't want you to discourage the other soldiers.
20.9: When the officials are finished giving these orders, they will appoint officers to be in command of the army.
20.16: Whenever you capture towns in the land the LORD your God is giving you, be sure to kill all the people and animals.
20.17: He has commanded you to completely wipe out the Hittites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
20.18: If you allow them to live, they will persuade you to worship their disgusting gods, and you will be unfaithful to the LORD.
20.19: When you are attacking a town, don't chop down its fruit trees, not even if you have had the town surrounded for a long time. Fruit trees aren't your enemies, and they produce food that you can eat, so don't cut them down.
20.20: You may need wood to make ladders and towers to help you get over the walls and capture the town. But use only trees that you know are not fruit trees.

21.1: Suppose the body of a murder victim is found in a field in the land the LORD your God is giving you, and no one knows who the murderer is.
21.2: The judges and other leaders from the towns around there must find out what town is the closest to where the body was found.
21.3: The leaders from that town will go to their cattle herds and choose a young cow that has never been put to work.
21.6: The town leaders will wash their hands over the body of the dead cow
21.7: and say, "We had no part in this murder, and we don't know who did it.
21.10: From time to time, you men will serve as soldiers and go off to war. The LORD your God will help you defeat your enemies, and you will take many prisoners.
21.14: Later on, if you are not happy with the woman, you can divorce her, and she can go free. But you have slept with her as your wife, so you cannot sell her as a slave or make her into your own slave.
21.18: A father and a mother may have a stubborn and rebellious son who refuses to obey them even after he has been punished.
21.19: If a son is like that, his parents must drag him to the town gate, where the leaders of the town hold their meetings.
21.20: The parents will tell the leaders, "This son of ours is stubborn and never obeys. He spends all his time drinking and partying."
21.21: The men of the town will stone that son to death, because they must get rid of the evil he brought into the community. Everyone in Israel will be afraid when they hear how he was punished.
21.22: If a criminal is put to death, and you hang the dead body on a tree,
21.23: you must not leave it there overnight. Bury it the same day, because the dead body of a criminal hanging on a tree will bring God's curse on the land. The LORD your God is giving this land to you, so don't make it unclean by leaving the bodies of executed criminals on display.

22.1: If you see a cow or sheep wandering around lost, take the animal back to its owner.
22.2: If the owner lives too far away, or if you don't know who the owner is, take the animal home with you and take care of it. The owner will come looking for the animal, and then you can give it back.
22.3: That's what you should do if you find anything that belongs to someone else. Do whatever you can to help, whether you find a cow or sheep or donkey or some clothing.
22.4: Oxen and donkeys that carry heavy loads can stumble and fall, and be unable to get up by themselves. So as you walk along the road, help anyone who is trying to get an ox or donkey back on its feet.
22.5: Women must not pretend to be men, and men must not pretend to be women. The LORD your God is disgusted with people who do that.
22.8: If you build a house, make sure to put a low wall around the edge of the flat roof. Then if someone falls off the roof and is killed, it won't be your fault.
22.9: If you plant a vineyard, don't plant any other fruit tree or crop in it. If you do plant something else there, you must bring to the place of worship everything you harvest from the vineyard.
22.10: Don't hitch an ox and a donkey to your plow at the same time.
22.11: When you weave cloth for clothing, you can use thread made of flax or wool, but not both together.
22.12: And when you make a coat, sew a tassel on each of the four corners.
22.13: Suppose a man starts hating his wife soon after they are married.
22.14: He might tell ugly lies about her, and say, "I married this woman, but when we slept together, I found out she wasn't a virgin."
22.15: If this happens, the bride's father and mother must go to the town gate to show the town leaders the proof that the woman was a virgin.
22.16: Her father will say, "I let my daughter marry this man, but he started hating her
22.17: and accusing her of not being a virgin. But he is wrong, because here is proof that she was a virgin!" Then the bride's parents will show them the bed sheet from the woman's wedding night.
22.18: The town leaders will beat the man with a whip
22.19: because he accused his bride of not being a virgin. He will have to pay her father 100 pieces of silver and will never be allowed to divorce her.
22.20: But if the man was right and there is no proof that his bride was a virgin,
22.21: the men of the town will take the woman to the door of her father's house and stone her to death. This woman brought evil into your community by sleeping with someone before she got married, and you must get rid of that evil by killing her.
22.22: People of Israel, if a man is caught having sex with someone else's wife, you must put them both to death. That way, you will get rid of the evil they have done in Israel.
22.25: If an engaged woman is raped out in the country, only the man will be put to death.
22.26: Do not punish the woman at all; she has done nothing wrong, and certainly nothing deserving death. This crime is like murder,
22.27: because the woman was alone out in the country when the man attacked her. She screamed, but there was no one to help her.
22.28: Suppose a woman isn't engaged to be married, and a man forces her to have sex with him. If he is caught,
22.29: they will be forced to get married. He must give her father 50 pieces of silver as a bride-price and can never divorce her.
22.30: A man must not marry a woman who was married to his father. This would be a disgrace to his father.

23.1: If a man's private parts have been crushed or cut off, he cannot fully belong to the LORD's people.
23.2: No one born outside of a legal marriage, or any of their descendants for ten generations, can fully belong to the LORD's people.
23.3: No Ammonites or Moabites, or any of their descendants for ten generations, can become part of Israel, the LORD's people.
23.4: This is because when you came out of Egypt, they refused to provide you with food and water. And besides, they hired Balaam to put a curse on you.
23.5: But the LORD your God loves you, so he refused to listen to Balaam and turned Balaam's curse into a blessing.
23.6: Don't even think of signing a peace treaty with Moab or Ammon.
23.7: But Edomites are your relatives, and you lived as foreigners in the country of Egypt. Now you must be kind to Edomites and Egyptians
23.8: and let their great-grandchildren become part of Israel, the LORD's people.
23.9: When you men go off to fight your enemies, make sure your camp is acceptable to the LORD.
23.10: For example, if something happens at night that makes a man unclean and unfit for worship, he must go outside the camp and stay there
23.11: until late afternoon. Then he must take a bath, and at sunset he can go back into camp.
23.12: Set up a place outside the camp to be used as a toilet area.
23.13: And make sure that you have a small shovel in your equipment. When you go out to the toilet area, use the shovel to dig a hole. Then, after you relieve yourself, bury the waste in the hole.
23.14: You must keep your camp clean of filthy and disgusting things. The LORD is always present in your camp, ready to rescue you and give you victory over your enemies. But if he sees something disgusting in your camp, he may turn around and leave.
23.15: When runaway slaves from other countries come to Israel and ask for protection, you must not hand them back to their owners.
23.16: Instead, you must let them choose which one of your towns they want to live in. Don't be cruel to runaway slaves.
23.17: People of Israel, don't any of you ever be temple prostitutes.
23.18: The LORD your God is disgusted with men and women who are prostitutes of any kind, and he will not accept a gift from them, even if it had been promised to him.
23.19: When you lend money, food, or anything else to another Israelite, you are not allowed to charge interest.
23.20: You can charge a foreigner interest. But if you charge other Israelites interest, the LORD your God will not let you be successful in the land you are about to take.
23.21: People of Israel, if you make a sacred promise to give a gift to the LORD, then do it as soon as you can. If the LORD has to come looking for the gift you promised, you will be guilty of breaking that promise.
23.22: On the other hand, if you never make a sacred promise, you can't be guilty of breaking it.
23.23: You must keep whatever promises you make to the LORD. After all, you are the one who chose to make the promises.
23.24: If you go into a vineyard that belongs to someone else, you are allowed to eat as many grapes as you want while you are there. But don't take any with you when you leave.
23.25: In the same way, if you are in a grain field that belongs to someone else, you can pick heads of grain and eat the kernels. But don't cut down the stalks of grain and take them with you.

24.1: Suppose a woman was divorced by her first husband because he found something disgraceful about her. He wrote out divorce papers, gave them to her, and sent her away.
24.3: who then either divorced her in the same way or died.
24.4: Since she has slept with her second husband, she cannot marry her first husband again. Their marriage would pollute the land that the LORD your God is giving you, and he would be disgusted.
24.5: If a man and a woman have been married less than one year, he must not be sent off to war or sent away to do forced labor. He must be allowed to stay home for a year and be happy with his wife.
24.6: When you lend money to people, you are allowed to keep something of theirs as a guarantee that they will pay back the loan. But don't take one or both of their millstones, or else they may starve. They need these stones for grinding grain into flour to make bread.
24.7: If you are guilty of kidnapping Israelites and forcing them into slavery, you will be put to death to remove this evil from the community.
24.8: I have told the priests what to do if any of you have leprosy, so do exactly what they say.
24.9: And remember what the LORD your God did to Miriam after you left Egypt.
24.10: When you lend money to people, you are allowed to keep something of theirs as a guarantee that the money will be paid back. But you must not go into their house to get it.
24.11: Wait outside, and they will bring out the item you have agreed on.
24.12: Suppose someone is so poor that a coat is the only thing that can be offered as a guarantee on a loan. Don't keep the coat overnight.
24.13: Instead, give it back before sunset, so the owner can keep warm and sleep and ask the LORD to bless you. Then the LORD your God will notice that you have done the right thing.
24.14: If you hire poor people to work for you, don't hold back their pay, whether they are Israelites or foreigners who live in your town.
24.15: Pay them their wages at the end of each day, because they live in poverty and need the money to survive. If you don't pay them on time, they will complain about you to the LORD, and he will punish you.
24.16: Parents must not be put to death for crimes committed by their children, and children must not be put to death for crimes committed by their parents. Don't put anyone to death for someone else's crime.
24.17: Make sure that orphans and foreigners are treated fairly. And if you lend money to a widow and want to keep something of hers to guarantee that she will pay you back, don't take any of her clothes.
24.18: You were slaves in Egypt until the LORD your God rescued you. That's why I am giving you these laws.
24.19: If you forget to bring in a stack of harvested grain, don't go back in the field to get it. Leave it for the poor, including foreigners, orphans, and widows, and the LORD will make you successful in everything you do.
24.20: When you harvest your olives, don't try to get them all for yourself, but leave some for the poor.
24.21: And when you pick your grapes, go over the vines only once, then let the poor have what is left.
24.22: You lived in poverty as slaves in Egypt until the LORD your God rescued you. That's why I am giving you these laws.

25.3: Forty lashes is the most that you can be given, because more than that might make other Israelites think you are worthless.
25.4: Don't muzzle an ox while it is threshing grain.

26.1: The LORD is giving you the land, and soon you will conquer it, settle down,

26.5: Then, standing there in front of the place of worship, you must pray: My ancestor was homeless, an Aramean who went to live in Egypt. There were only a few in his family then, but they became great and powerful, a nation of many people.

26.7: We called out for help to you, the LORD God of our ancestors. You heard our cries; you knew we were in trouble and abused.
26.8: Then you terrified the Egyptians with your mighty miracles and rescued us from Egypt.
26.9: You brought us here and gave us this land rich with milk and honey.
26.10: Now, LORD, I bring to you the best of the crops that you have given me. After you say these things, place the basket in front of the LORD's altar and bow down to worship him.
26.11: Then you and your family must celebrate by eating a meal at the place of worship to thank the LORD your God for giving you such a good harvest. And remember to invite the Levites and the foreigners who live in your town.
